prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:hi there how are you doing?
seeker:Hi, doing OK. how are you doing?
supporter:I am not so bad. Is there anything you'd like to talk about?
seeker:I am having difficulty in controlling my anxiety and look for some support.
supporter:Ah I hear you, I have suffered bad anxiety for years. Have you been getting medical help?
seeker:Not really, although I got some medication prescribed, however, am very afraid of getting addicted and reliance.
supporter:Some anti anxiety medication can be addictive but if you're sensible with it you should be okay. Talk to your doctor?
seeker:Yes, she suggested so. But I am not convinced.
seeker:I see many friends getting relying on the medication even after they feel OK.
supporter:What about counselling .. would you consider that? There is some very good therapy available
seeker:I haven't thought about it...maybe not familiar with the circumstance.
seeker:Maybe different culture that I have grown?
seeker:I also have many friends who were not satisfied with counseling.
supporter:True - I know different cultures do take different approaches to things and in some places talking about mental health is taboo
seeker:I have no idea what to do.
seeker:that's why I look for another support.
supporter:I would recommend giving counselling a go, even though you're not totally sure about it
seeker:what if it doesn't work and cost a lot?
supporter:Is it not possible to get it free? It is provided free in my country
seeker:very costy here in the US
supporter:Ah, you need to move here to the UK ;)
seeker:also varying by the healthcare providers.
seeker:I didn't know that the UK has such a good coverage.
supporter:We don't have to worry about the cost of medication or counselling as we have socialised medicine
seeker:can you please explain further about socialized medicine?
supporter:Sure. Everyone pays a small percentage of their income - depending on how much they earn - and it goes to fund the NHS. Everyone is therefore eligible for free hospital treatment etc and we pay a standard amount (about ten pounds ie fourteen dollars) for a prescription, no matter which drugs we are gettign
supporter:If I needed a heart transplant tomorrow it would be free :D
seeker:I see. That's how South Korea manage healthcare too.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hi there, can you help me?
supporter:I'll do my best. What do you need help with?
seeker:I feel depressed because I had to quit my job and stay home with my kids because of their remote school.
supporter:I can understand why that would make you feel depressed.
seeker:Do you have any advice on how to feel better?
supporter:Yes of course. It's good that you are acknowledging your feelings. To improve your mood you could practice hobbies or other things you enjoy doing.
seeker:I see. Yes I do enjoy knitting. I just don't feel like I have time to do that.
supporter:I can understand how you feel that you don't have time.
seeker:When I do have time I feel too exhausted to do anything else.
supporter:Parents need to learn to take care of their own needs first before their children. Only then can you be truly available for anyone else.
seeker:You're right, I need to find time for me.
supporter:Indeed, once you free up some time for yourself, I bet you'll start to feel better.
seeker:Do you have other suggestions?
supporter:Yes, try meditation for a few minutes each morning.
seeker:What do I do to meditate?
supporter:Take a few deep breaths and clear your mind of negative thoughts.
seeker:That sounds good, but how will it help.
supporter:meditation allows you to set up your day in your mind and let you be calm.
seeker:Will that help me get through the day and be happy?
supporter:Yes, it won't happen overnight but be patient with it.
seeker:Ok thanks.
supporter:do you have any other concerns?
seeker:no I think you helped me enough.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Going to the store gives me Panic Attacks! Driving also makes me highly anxious.
seeker:I am on medication but this only seems to help moderately.
supporter:Hello
seeker:Hi
supporter:So just to ensure that I understand you correctly, you are feeling anxious about going to the store during the pandemic
seeker:No. This has been going on before the pandemic
seeker:COVID didn't cause my anxiety
supporter:Okay, so just general anxiety about it then.
seeker:Yessir
supporter:How long have you had this anxiety issue?
seeker:Only the past couple of years. It came on suddenly at a nail salon after I had an allergic reaction to a chemical in acrylic nails.
seeker:Originally the doctors thought it was brain inflammation.
seeker:What suggestions do you have for improving it?
seeker:Meditation?
seeker:Exercise?
seeker:I do art. And never have anxiety when I'm painting, however, I cannot exactly do that at the store
supporter:Have you thought about looking for support groups with people who also have anxiety about being in public?
seeker:I have and I did
supporter:Have you thought about brining a friend with you to the store? Someone you are comfortable with? Having someone you are comfortable with may help to calm the anxiety while you are out.
seeker:Support groups don't really help stop the Panic Attacks. They cause all sorts of sensations. Fast heart rate, chills, shakes, My brain feels foggy and impersonal.
seeker:I do go to the store often with my fiance :)
seeker:That has helped a lot
supporter:I have also had anxiety in the past when in public places, so I know how it feels to be anxious while out.
seeker:Yeah, it's definitely annoying. But it isn't JUST at the store. I was diagnosed with Panic Attack Disorder and even have attacks at home where I freak out.
seeker:It's been better since I was on medication but I never feel completely....normal
supporter:Another thing that may help is having some headphones in attached to your phone or an MP3 player so you can have some calming music or something in your ear while you are out.
seeker:That's actually a really good idea. Distractions definitely seem to be the way to go for me.
seeker:That's probably why art helps so much
supporter:I found that distractions were great for me too!
seeker:I wonder if it should be calming music or music that I generally feel like dancing too
seeker:I know that sometimes calming music kinda makes me more centered and aware of myself which can exacerbate the problems sometimes.
seeker:I usually listen to music loudly when Im in my car to help with the anxiety
seeker:Of course, I always think its working then I get to the store and my hands hurt from gripping my steering wheel so hard XD
supporter:Whatever music you think would be best would be a good idea.
seeker:I think a lot of my anxiety doesnt stem from social stuff but from a fear of death tbh
seeker:What other distractions can you reccomend?
seeker:*recommend
supporter:Do you have a stress ball or something you can keep with you in your pocket while out?
seeker:I don't!

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello, how are you doing?
seeker:Well, my fiance and I "sort of" broke up recently. I moved out of our place and all, but we continued to see each other at least 3X per week. And we both said we're not 100% sure that we're ok with us being done for good. - We promised to tell each other if we start dating anyone. He said he wasn't interested in dating. Three days after that conversation, I come over unexpectedly to find him making dinner for a woman I've never seen before. Turns out it was his 3rd date with her. He met her on a dating app a week before our conversation about promising to tell each other if we start dating others.
supporter:I'm so sorry that happened. Are you mostly hurt because he didn't tell you he was seeing somebody else?
seeker:To be honest, I'd still be hurt if he told me. But now on top of that hurt, I feel disrespected... and everything I thought I knew about him is kind of crushed. We were together 6 years, and I always, ALWAYS believed he was the most honest, kind, "stand up guy" I've  ever known.
supporter:You must feel really torn up about it. I can tell that you care about your relationship.
seeker:Yes, that's true. The worst part is that he doesn't seem to think I have a right to be hurt. How do I even deal with someone who hurt me but doesn't care to take any responsibility whatsoever?
supporter:Maybe he didn't intend to hurt you. Its not like he invited you over to tease you. It is true that he didn't keep his promise, and that's his fault.
seeker:That's true. He didn't invite me over. I expected him to be at work that night. I was coming over to see our cats, which still all lived with him. I still had a key and it didn't occur to me that I could invade his privacy since I had been spending 3X a week with him, and he was fine with me using the key. The whole thing was a shock. I wouldn't have come in had I known what I'd find inside.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:How are you tonight?
seeker:Hello, I've had trouble with depression all my life but it hasn't been so bad in the past few years. But lately, with the pandemic, I seem to be sinking lower and lower
supporter:So it's been more difficult for you to remain cheerful since the plandemic?
seeker:Well, I'm still taking my medication, but now, I seem to be anxious all the time.
seeker:I really haven't been anxious for over 20 years, but this year has made me a mess!
supporter:I actually have struggled with depression and anxiety most of my life so I can understand.
seeker:It's great to talk to someone who actually knows what it feels like!
seeker:I've had friends to tell me, "just snap out of it"
supporter:That doesn't sound helpful at all.
supporter:I have found a few things I do to keep myself from being to worried and depressed. They help a lot.
seeker:It isn't, but I guess it's because they don't really know what *depression* feels like.
seeker:Really? What do you do? Maybe they could help me.
supporter:True, many people do not understand depression. I actually have found it easier to find a person who DOES understand and not talk to those who don't. When I talk to those who don't, it brings me down, so I find a good friend I can confide in.
supporter:I can understand being discouraged to and not knowing who will understand you.
seeker:Yes!! Talking to someone who doesn't know what it feels like REALLY makes me depressed!
seeker:I'm wondering if it is the pandemic that is making me feel worse?
supporter:I find it important to take care of my physical being first: eat well, drink water, exercise, get fresh air. Don't wear the mask if you can help it. Seeing smiles helps.
seeker:I haven't been exercising nearly as much since March. Maybe I need to start walking again.
supporter:I personally don't know anyone who has died and my nurse friends say it is no worse than the flu. So I try not to worry. What I think about is so critical. I try to pray about what I can't handle, then move on, change my thoughts.
supporter:Walking is GREAT! This is a lovely time of year too!
seeker:I have a friend who did get it and almost died. He is 40 and pretty healthy. His wife and daughter got it too. They just had flu-like symptoms, but he was in the hospital for 9 days.
seeker:That was almost 3 months ago and he is still feeling the effects of it.
supporter:So to recap, find a good friend, get exercise, eat well, talk to people who will try to understand you.  And of course, pray.  The survival rate is 99.996% so the fact that you know no one who died is good news. I had flu like symptoms before this all happened and I still have a cough. They spray the skies too, so I try to not live in fear. There are a lot of consequences to fear, your heart beats faster, you stress yourself out, so it's important to not focus on negativity for too long.
seeker:I like your idea of changing thoughts. That would help keep me from "going down the rabbit hole!"
seeker:I had a bad cough and got tested several weeks ago just in case. But I didn't have it.
supporter:Here is a good saying -- if you want to change your feelings, change your thinking.  Feelings are like the tail on the dog, they follow thoughts. So keep your thoughts positive, cultivate an attitude of gratitude, even write a list of of things you are thankful for.
seeker:LOL! That's great!  I'll have to remember that "feelings are like the tail of the dog"!  That's a cheerful way of thinking about it!
supporter:I'm almost 60 and my husband is 66. We refuse to live in fear. These are difficult times, no doubt, but I believe if you take the time to pursue good healthy, you will be better for it, emotionally and mentally and physically. All around!
supporter:Well, I hope I have encouraged you.
seeker:Yes, I think walking, changing my thoughts, praying, and taking care of myself will really help. Yes! You've really helped me out.
seeker:I just turned 64 and my husband is 69. He is really, really healthy because he takes care of himself so well.
seeker:He has a handicapped younger sister and he always wanted to be around to take care of her. So he has always taken care of himself!
seeker:Thanks so much!
supporter:So we are about the same age then! I encourage you to write down the strategy, while the ideas are simple, sometimes they are NOT easy! We must make a choice to do what is healthy! God bless you!

supporter:and in that case you are no worse off

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Im so depressed
supporter:I am really sorry to hear that.
seeker:It just wont end
supporter:What is making things so hard?
seeker:Now Im in quaritine again cant leave the house
seeker:I dont have anyone to tak to
supporter:I definitely understand that. I also have been having a hard time in quarantine.
seeker:Plus my work hours have been cut
supporter:Do you have people you can talk to digitally? Friends, family?
seeker:I have family but they live on the west coast im on the eastcoast
supporter:I get that. It can be really frustrating when you feel alone and like you've got no one to talk to. Especially when 2020 seems to be dumping things on you.
supporter:What have you been doing to pass the time? Is there anything that you've found that makes you feel better?
seeker:So my money is now running low and rent is coming due
seeker:I like to read
supporter:That can be handy!
seeker:I like to walk on the beach
supporter:Is that something you can do with regularity? Getting out and walking?
supporter:I know that I've had good luck battling my depression by just finding ways to not be at home. Hiking, going for walks, going for drives...
seeker:Yes I live on the beach but its so cold right now I cant even do that. I feal so isolated
seeker:Im going to do that tomorrow
supporter:Good! It's hard to start, but it's a good way to start. How far do you plan on going?
seeker:Im going to bundle up and go to the beach. Probably walk down to the pier 1 mile
supporter:That will be good. Make sure you can take some time and really appreciate not being in the house.
supporter:Is there any music or podcats you can listen to while out?
seeker:Thats good advice, Im feeling a little better
seeker:I can take my iphone for music
supporter:I am glad. Practicing mindfulness can really help, and help put things in perspective. Often times we build things up to be even worse than they already are. Being able to be grateful for what's around can help, without diminishing the issues that you are facing.
seeker:Thats good advice, thanks I think you helped me
supporter:Remembering that it's okay to be sad and depressed, as much as it sucks, can be helpful in reframing. It's a rough time for everyone and you definitely are not alone.
seeker:Thats true, it just seems like I am alone cause well I am lol
supporter:I absolutely get it. I work from home right now so it's just me all day. Sometimes, I literally only talk to my cats. I am a crazy cat lady.
seeker:Cats are cool
supporter:I had a whole cry and freak out moment when part 2 of quarantine hit recently. I wholeheartedly understand.
supporter:Do you have any pets?
seeker:I have a Russian Blue cat ssmart very smart cat
supporter:Smart cats are the best. They know when you need cuddles, which it sounds like you do! Also means you aren't alone. ;) Cat needs ya! As much as they don't want to admit it.
seeker:He's my buddy for sure.  Makes me happy to think of him
supporter:If you are healthy/feel comfortable with going out, you could consider volunteering at an animal shelter. You'd get to interact with some folks, some animals, and add something to the resume. I don't know if you are likely to get hours back at work or what you do, but that could be fun!
seeker:Thats a good idea I'll look into it.  Well we better wrap this hit up?
supporter:I believe it needs to be a minimum of 20 minutes and we are at 17 right now.
supporter:For the max that is, lol.
seeker:Oh sorry thought it was 15 minutes. So where are you at?
supporter:West Coast of all things! WA st, so lots of hiking for me. It's been helping so much.
seeker:I moved from Renton to here in Myrtle Beach SC
supporter:Oh hey! So all of your family is here then. What prompted the move?
seeker:Got real tired of the weather and people there
seeker:Everyone friendly here and actually talk to one another
supporter:Ha. I believe that. I was born and raised in Puyallup, so it's all I know. i couldn't ever think of leaving.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hello there. In the past 3 years, I have gotten into 2 car accidents. Neither of them were my fault. I sustained a concussion/traumatic brain injury and am experiencing depression and PTSD.
seeker:I have nightmares of crashing at least 2x a week. I am seeing a therapist, but due to the pandemic we are not meeting in person to do EDMR for my PTSD
supporter:Hello, I'm so sorry to hear that. That sounds like an awful lot to go through in a few years time, which now can feel like the time passes so quickly.
seeker:I have a traumatic brain injury that creates a lot of overstimulation in my life. I used to be social and now I can't be in a social setting for too long without feeling exhausted
supporter:Have you tried to talk to your therapist through video chat or is that something they offer?
seeker:Yes, I talk to my therapist every other week
supporter:That's great that they can offer that, I know it's very difficult to get regular care at the moment with the pandemic.
supporter:Do you have any family or friends close by or something that you can talk to if you feel like you need some extra support?
seeker:I do not have supportive or understanding friends and family
seeker:I have lost a lot of them in the last few years or have created boundaries because when I got into my first car accident, legit someone said "are you not better yet?" and another said "can't you just walk it off?"
seeker:When I got into my second car accident, people said "again? are you drunk?"
seeker:Even though neither were my fault, people were not understanding or asked how scary those situations for me were
supporter:I am sorry to hear that, people are very quick to judge so it's very unfortunate that you were treated that way.
seeker:After my first car accident, the tow truck guy was towing my car to my aunt's garage to hold for auto insurance appraisal. He said to my aunt "sorry for your loss" My aunt said "oh, she's right over there and alive"
seeker:the car accident was so bad the tow truck guy thought I had died
seeker:but even after seeing my car, friends and family acted like it was just something that happens to everyone. walk it off
supporter:Wow, I can't imagine what the car must have looked like then for such a comment to be made. I'm glad that you here and despite going through that trauma that you are still going.
seeker:Thanks.
supporter:A women fell asleep at the wheel in 2013 and hit me going through an intersection and totaled by car as well, but I had only had a concussion and pain I had to go to physical therapy for a short time, so I can't imagine how you must have felt.
seeker:What are some things you do when you have depression? Have you been in a scary car accident before or know anyone? Have you offered them kindness or you just dismissed them and thought it was their own problem?
seeker:That sounds scary. And is extremely unfortunate.
supporter:I'm sorry that you didn't get the support you needed after your accidents because it's hard enough to go through the pain and trauma (mental and physical) to begin with and the support is much needed.
seeker:Absolutely! But I'm doing better now. You find out who your real friends and family are and you move on. The whole saying of "they don't deserve you at your best when they weren't there when you were at your worst"
supporter:You are 100% correct. Have you looked into any support groups at all or tried to connect with anyone with similar experiences through social media?
seeker:I don't use social media
seeker:I quit in 2016, which is also when I started realizing how vain people are
seeker:Some of those same friends and family didn't bother to text me even though they had my number
seeker:I did find a local group that did social stuff together but they were all really old like 50 years plus
seeker:I'm in my 20s so it was hard to relate
supporter:Gotcha! Well I'm glad I was able to connect with you this evening because sometimes it helps just to chat and have someone listen :-)
seeker:Thanks! I appreciate it. Happy Holidays and Happy New Year

supporter:Hello
seeker:Hi
supporter:How is everything
seeker:Not the best.  I have been quarantined for 5 weeks with COVID-19 (tested positive), so I am getting cabin fever.
supporter:Ready for the holidays
supporter:So you tested positive, must be hard
seeker:I am starting to get an aversion to holidays.  When I was in college, my father was dying, and Thanksgiving was the last meal he ate at the family table...
Christmas was the last time he ate solid food,
and he died on the day after Epiphany
seeker:So I have come to associate Thanksgiving through January as a time of loss.
supporter:The holidays can bring back memories, but you have other family around right
seeker:This month has driven it home more, because I have had six people die this month.  It's starting to bring on flashbacks.
seeker:No, my family all moved from the area.  The nearest is now half a country away and hasn't spoken to me in over ten years.
supporter:The virus is hard. along with the season
seeker:It's been... interesting.
supporter:You must have friends around, right. have you contacted any
supporter:How long ago did your dad pass away
seeker:Ahhh... I hate to be that guy, but I really don't have that many friends.  I have a couple people at my church who have checked in, but I wouldn't go so far as to call them friends (we don't hang out, I don't get invited over...)
seeker:I was in college.  He died slowly and painfully.  It was really unpleasant.
seeker:And he was a brilliant man.  I could only wish to be half of what he was.

seeker:I think they forgot about me.

seeker:The only one I still have contact with is my mother.

seeker:I talk to her regularly.  She is okay, but I fear she is reaching the age where I know I won't have her much longer.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:How are you tonight?
seeker:Hello, I've had trouble with depression all my life but it hasn't been so bad in the past few years. But lately, with the pandemic, I seem to be sinking lower and lower
supporter:So it's been more difficult for you to remain cheerful since the plandemic?
seeker:Well, I'm still taking my medication, but now, I seem to be anxious all the time.
seeker:I really haven't been anxious for over 20 years, but this year has made me a mess!
supporter:I actually have struggled with depression and anxiety most of my life so I can understand.
seeker:It's great to talk to someone who actually knows what it feels like!
seeker:I've had friends to tell me, "just snap out of it"
supporter:That doesn't sound helpful at all.
supporter:I have found a few things I do to keep myself from being to worried and depressed. They help a lot.
seeker:It isn't, but I guess it's because they don't really know what *depression* feels like.
seeker:Really? What do you do? Maybe they could help me.
supporter:True, many people do not understand depression. I actually have found it easier to find a person who DOES understand and not talk to those who don't. When I talk to those who don't, it brings me down, so I find a good friend I can confide in.
supporter:I can understand being discouraged to and not knowing who will understand you.
seeker:Yes!! Talking to someone who doesn't know what it feels like REALLY makes me depressed!
seeker:I'm wondering if it is the pandemic that is making me feel worse?
supporter:I find it important to take care of my physical being first: eat well, drink water, exercise, get fresh air. Don't wear the mask if you can help it. Seeing smiles helps.
seeker:I haven't been exercising nearly as much since March. Maybe I need to start walking again.
supporter:I personally don't know anyone who has died and my nurse friends say it is no worse than the flu. So I try not to worry. What I think about is so critical. I try to pray about what I can't handle, then move on, change my thoughts.
supporter:Walking is GREAT! This is a lovely time of year too!
seeker:I have a friend who did get it and almost died. He is 40 and pretty healthy. His wife and daughter got it too. They just had flu-like symptoms, but he was in the hospital for 9 days.
seeker:That was almost 3 months ago and he is still feeling the effects of it.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello! How are you doing today?
seeker:I'm not doing so well. I'm really lonely and kind of sad.
supporter:I'm so sorry to hear that.
supporter:Do you mind me asking what is going on that is making you feel this way?
seeker:Thank you. I broke up with my girlfriend. It was the right thing to do, but now I'm really lonely and sad.
supporter:I'm so sorry to hear that. It sounds to me like you're having a hard time dealing with the emotions that you're dealing with after having broken up with your girlfriend. Does this sound right?
seeker:Yes, that's right. It's been really hard.
supporter:I can tell that you're really struggling.
seeker:Thank you. I was with her for about a year. It was good at first, of course.
supporter:I've dealt with these emotions myself. I recently broke up with my now ex-boyfriend. I have been feeling these same emotions.
seeker:I'm sorry to hear that. How long were you together? The loneliness gets so hard, especially when you just want to tell something to someone.
supporter:I know it feels terrible, but I think that you reaching out for support is a great first step! I'm really proud of you! You will get through this!
seeker:Thank you. Honestly, I'm glad you're there to reach out to.
supporter:We were together for about 5 years. Yes, the loneliness does get very hard.
supporter:I'm happy that I can be here to help you and so that you have someone to talk to! I promise to do my best!
seeker:Oh wow, that's a long time. And thanks. I appreciate your optimism! I am usually very upbeat and optimistic myself.
seeker:Thank you. I really appreciate it. Hopefully I can help you somehow too.
supporter:After my breakup, I found that the best thing to do was to involve myself in other activities that I enjoyed in order to take my mind off of the negative feelings that I was dealing with.
seeker:The shiba inu in my profile circle is making me smile. I used to have a shiba inu. :)
supporter:You seem very kind! I appreciate your willingness to be here for and to listen to me as well!
supporter:Aww! That makes me happy to hear that seeing my profile picture is making you smile!
seeker:That sounds really smart. I've been trying to do that. Of course with a pandemic going on it's more difficult.
supporter:Have you considered getting into any hobbies to take your mind off of what's going on?
seeker:No no... my profile picture. Yours shows up as a squirrel. lol
seeker:I usually hike a lot, but my hiking groups aren't going out right now.
supporter:Oh! I'm so sorry! Haha!
supporter:Have you considered things like journaling, reading, or arts and crafts?
seeker:Maybe I should get a pet squirrel?
seeker:Yes, I actually read and write quite a bit. Especially for work. That's not overly therapeutic, but it helps nonetheless.
supporter:That may not be a bad idea! If you really like them and are able to properly care for it, animals can be very therapeutic!
seeker:I have one dog who isn't much bigger than a squirrel. She has been an invaluable companion.
supporter:Writing and reading have been proven to be extremely therapeutic. I used to write down my feelings on a piece of paper and then destroy it (throw it away) once I was done. There's something about it that really seems to help.
supporter:Aww! That sounds like an adorable dog! What breed of dog is she? I have two cats myself. They make me feel better on a daily basis!
seeker:I've tried to keep a journal but I never stick to it. I find that writing letters to friends serves me the same purpose, and it helps me to stay connected, too. Plus, people love getting real, hand-written mail.
seeker:She is a miniature dachshund. Today she went to the bank with me, and all of the tellers came to the window to look into the car at her. lol  I like cats too. Animals are so healing.
supporter:That sounds like a great idea! I love the fact that it helps you to stay connected, especially considering (as you already mentioned) that it's difficult to connect right now since we're dealing with COVID-19.
supporter:I love that you're telling me about your dog and how all of the people at the bank wanted to see her! I bet that made you feel much better.
seeker:Yeah, and you're right. There's something therapeutic and cathartic about hand writing that typing does not replicate.
seeker:Yes, it made me happy to see them fawning over her. And it made her happy because they gave her treats.
seeker:Dealing with issues during Covid is so rough.
supporter:I couldn't agree more. Dealing with COVID on top of everything else has been extremely difficult for me. Honestly, I think it is part of what caused a lot of the issues that I'm currently dealing with.
seeker:I hope you're handling them okay. I'm generally well except for the whole breakup business. Still, I know I'm better off. It just sucks sometimes.
supporter:It makes me happy to hear that you know that you're better off. I know it's sad, but accepting that a relationship wasn't meant to be is, in my opinion, the first step to truly getting over someone. A year is a long time to spend with one person.
seeker:I wish it was easier and okay to travel right now. A trip or a road trip would do me wonders.
seeker:So is five years! I hope everything works out for the best for you, too.

It happened a couple of months ago. I wish I could get over it. I can't get her off my mind. She's dating this total loser.
supporter:That's tough... so you're saying that you grew apart a little? Or do you think it was more one-sided?
seeker:It probably was more me than her. 
Maybe I should have done more to show her that I cared for her. Am I not romantic enough? Some guys just aren't that way.
supporter:I completely understand, and I don't think you should beat yourself up over it!
seeker:That's a fair point. I shouldn't be too hard on myself.  I didn't really grow up in a romantic family. I don't know how to do that stuff, but maybe I could learn.
supporter:Exactly, and remember everyone is different, perhaps you just weren't her right one, and that can go both ways.
supporter:Do you want to improve for her? or for yourself do you think?
seeker:That's true. I really got hung up on her. I thought she was perfect and that we were perfect together. She didn't see it that way. I can't really change who I am, and she couldn't change who she is.
seeker:I don't know if I can change myself for her. Maybe there is something basic that she wants that I just don't have? I should probably change for future relationships.
supporter:That's a great line of thought, its good that you're able to identify that yourself
seeker:What do you think I could do to improve myself?
supporter:I suggest that you stay exactly the way that you are. I feel like you'd be happier that way and also more likely to find someone who shares the same values as you
supporter:If you change who you are, it sort of means that your ex still has a hold on you, you know?
seeker:Will the same problems show up in the next relationship though? It could be a long search before I find someone that matches with me?

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hello.
supporter:Hello, how are you at the moment? My name is Jo
seeker:I am doing okay I suppose.. How are you??
supporter:I am not so bad. Is there anything you'd like to talk to me about today?
seeker:Yes. I had to throw out my sister the other day and Im kind of upset over it.
supporter:I am sorry to hear that. What precipitated that, had you been having problems for a while?
seeker:She was in a psych ward for a while and when it was time to discharge her, my mother didnt want her back. She was going to send her to a foster home so I volunteered to take her in.
seeker:Since then, she has stopped taking her medication and is acting out.
supporter:Ah, so you feel as though your mother could and should have helped and you were put into an impossible position you were not prepared for?
seeker:Pretty much.
supporter:I can sympathise with you having siblings with extreme mental health problems - I have been there too and I know how difficult it is.
seeker:I tried to have  my mother take her back, but she still didnt want her there. So I sent her to my grandmothers and she turned that side of the family against me.
supporter:Mentally ill people can unfortunately sometimes be manipulative, though they do not mean it. Have you had any contact with her since?
seeker:Only once and she was just telling me that I was a horrible person.
seeker:This all started over her stopping her meds and then I asked her to clean her room.
supporter:That sounds very toxic. Is it possible to persuade her to seek medical help? I realise she might be reluctant to
seeker:We have tried to get her into therapy again. But, COVID put a block on that.
seeker:I suggested that she go back to the ward and maybe be placed into a group home.
supporter:Ah yes, it is a terrible time at the moment isn't it? I think a lot of people are not getting the medical help that they need because of the virus
supporter:Please do not beat yourself up over this - it does sound as though you have done absolutely everything you could to help.
seeker:I would hate to see that happen, but Im at my wits end.
supporter:I can tell that you feel really bad about this just from your  tone of voice. Please remember that you can't fix everything in the world.
seeker:Now my dads side of the family hates me because they say Im "mean to her". All I asked her to do was to clean her room and maybe socialize every once in a while.
seeker:Im more mad than sad.
supporter:Socialising can be hard for people with mental health problems. It might have been best if you did not press her too hard to do that though I know you did not realise.
seeker:I understand, but I think it would have better than sitting in a dark room all day.
supporter:Does she suffer from depression also? That might account for her trying to shut herself away
seeker:Yes, but she denies it whole heartedly.
seeker:This is why she was taking medication.
supporter:I understand that it can be very difficult to make people take medication if they refuse to recognise that they have a problem.
seeker:I just wish she could she what I see...
supporter:Unfortunately that is not likely to be possible. All you can do is be kind to yourself and know that you really did try to help her
seeker:I was afraid she was going to ruin my family with her attitudes.

supporter:same as u right
seeker:no, I'm female.
supporter:Are there any other females working with you
seeker:currently, no. the new person he's looking to hire to take over eventually is female.
supporter:I assume you are full time

supporter:So you seem qualified for the position, have you been able to ask why he overlooked you
supporter:Being overlooked because of personal reasons should not  be a reason to offer the position to an outsider

seeker:I think may be because my approach to things are a little more subtle. I tend to get a long with people in different departments more than he does. I'm "not aggressive enough" he's said in the past. But I just think it's a different approach on how to handle matters.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hi
supporter:Hello there, how is your day going?
seeker:It's going okay. I'm just having a hard time.
supporter:Is there something that you'd like to talk about?
seeker:It's mainly my husband. His spending habits are out of control. He thinks he need to reward himself for living. We can't survive if he keeps gifting himself.
supporter:Wow that sounds like a big problem. Is he aware of how much distress this is causing you?
seeker:I've tried talking to him about it, but he claims that he needs to reward himself or he wouldn't do anything. Like, if he gets up and goes to work then he needs to eat out to reward himself.
supporter:So you feel that he is misunderstanding life? That he feels that he deserves things just for existing?
seeker:Exactly. And if I push further, he compares himself to other people: "Well, at least I don't hit you." or "At least I'm not an alcoholic" Like I should thank him for existing.
supporter:It sounds like a really toxic relationship - I hear you! I have been in that position also. In the end I felt that I had no choice but to leave. I cannot tell you what to do, though.
seeker:It's hard because we have children. When we were just dating, he was a different person. He didn't start to act this way until after our eldest was born.
supporter:Ah, unfortunately a lot of men are like that - before you become seriously committed they seem totally different. Have you considered seeking professional help?
seeker:The problem all boils down to money. If I had enough for therapy I wouldn't be worried about his spending habits! lol. But, you're right, that's probably what we both need!
supporter:I believe that there are some organisations that will offer free therapy sessions for people in need. Have you considered asking your doctor?
seeker:Really? I'd definitely be interested in that. Do they have online therapy like that?
supporter:I am not totally sure what is available but I think that there might be such things
seeker:Thanks for your help. You said you've been in similar relationships. Is this behavior common for men?
supporter:Well no, I don't think that all men are like this by any stretch of the imagination. Unfortunately, however, there are some bad apples who give all men a bad name. I am sure that the same applies to women too though!
seeker:Haha, true. I just wondered. I had previous relationships, but they were very short.  My dad was always the opposite: he was a penny-pincher. Sometimes I worry that maybe I'm just to stingy with the money, but then I remember that we have none, so Idk how to be more generous lol
supporter:You sound to me as though you are being realistic and sensible about your financial situation and are being neither too stingy nor too lavish.
seeker:Thank you for your help and feedback. I appreciate it. I'm going to select Finish & Quit
supporter:I hope that I have been able to be of some help to you!

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello, how are you today?
seeker:Hey, I've been having a really rough day.
seeker:My mom and I got into an argument
supporter:I'm sorry to hear that, what's happening?
supporter:How bad was the argument?  What was it about?
seeker:She got pretty upset when I took off my shower head without telling her. Somehow, we ended up arguing about how I don't respect her.
supporter:Do you think there is any truth to what she is saying?
supporter:Family conflict can be very upsetting, I have it in my family sometimes.
seeker:Maybe. I don't particularly like her and that she maybe picks up on that. But I feel like that's the underlying issue and the shower head argument is just a coverup for her real feelings.
seeker:It's really upsetting. We have "peaceful" moments before we're arguing again
supporter:I see.   Do you live together?
seeker:Yes
supporter:That does sound upsetting.   So how do you two make peace generally, or do you have silences between you?
seeker:I guess it's less peace and more like silence
supporter:So what helps you deal with it?  I have found journaling so helpful when I have personal conflicts.  It helps to get things in perspective, and to vent to a peice of paper
supporter:Actually I journal on my computer, and don't save it :)
seeker:I've written some of our arguments down before, but it's too painful to look at now.
supporter:Thath's why I don't save my journal entries, too painful
seeker:I used to talk to friends about it, but idk, it all feels empty now.
supporter:Do you have a counselor you can speak with about how to deal with the conflicts?   Maybe he/she could arrange a family meeting
seeker:I get that. It's hard to look at them. I'm not sure what to do to cope. Lately, my coping skills haven't been all to healthy
supporter:I did that with my husband when we were fighting, having a counselor in the room helped us gain insight.
seeker:I have a psychiatrist and I'm trying to figure out how to pay for a therapy currently. I know some offer sliding scale options
supporter:Exercise is helpful for burning off anger, a good long walk... Oh you must be in US?
seeker:Yeah, I'm in the U.S. I used to go on walks and exercise at night. It really helps me sleep.
seeker:Maybe I can start doing that again
supporter:I think that would be great!   A good way to burn off frustration and improve physical health at the same time.
seeker:I always fall out of it! Any advice for making a steady habit out of it?
supporter:You will get through this....it sounds like you two need to have some good talks to address these conflicts....together the two of you may be able to sort it out.   On a day when things are calm, not during an argument.
supporter:Yes I do!   I used to procrastinate walking....then I got myself a walking partner
seeker:That sounds great! I've been wanting a workout partner, I think a friend of mines wants one too...

supporter:So you are unhappy at your job and want to do something else? What exactly are your fears?
supporter:I have found writing out a pro and con list helps me -- On one side I look at the benefits, then I put the cons on the other side. They I weigh them, even if there are more cons, sometimes the PROS are much better.
seeker:I am a helpdesk associate for a large telecom company. I don't like the hours and the pay here but I am afraid if I can get a job outside in this time.
supporter:I can understand that looking for a job can be stressful and challenging at this time, but one thing is for certain, you will never know if you don't try.
seeker:I have tried the Pros & Cons method. Pros are better pay and hours, cons are tougher interviews and more rounds
seeker:Yes, I think I need to give a try but I lack the confidence to put my resume out in the market.
supporter:I like the "Do it afraid!" method. I can still try even if I feel nervous.  You really do not need confidence to put your resume out there, you just need to do it afraid. And when I "do it afraid" I realize it was easier than I thought.
seeker:"Do it afraid"? Do you mean do it even if I am afraid? It sounds a bit too optimistic to me.
supporter:I used to be paralyzed with self confidence, but the truth is, your confidence doesn't come from your job, your confidence comes from being a lovable person. The confidence that you are the person you want to be.
supporter:It sounds optimistic but it is the truth, when I step out to perform, I'm always nervous. BEING nervous looking for a job, that is NORMAL. To expect to feel like you are super confident is unrealistic. Most people are nervous, but they do it anyway.
seeker:Ok, I think it makes sense. I may have to give it a try.
supporter:I always felt awkward and nervous looking for a job, I think I went to one interview calm and cool, in 30 years! Hahaha.
seeker:I am a good team player, I don't have any inter-personal or communication issues. Just that I need to be at a higher pay to reach some financial goals
supporter:You have nothing to lose, really, you have weighed out that there is only good things that can come, but you think you must "feel" a certain way. You don not have to feel confident, you just have to do the work. For example, you don't FEEL like walking your dog, changing a diaper or helping someone, but you DO IT anyway.
seeker:Cool! I will try to get motivated and start applying. Your words are just what I needed in this gloomy atmosphere.
supporter:Inter personal skills can be learned. I was very shy as a child and I learned how to be more friendly. And I was VERY shy.
seeker:Ya, I think the key is to keep my current job and start looking elsewhere.
seeker:Last time I made a grave mistake of quitting my job and then searching! I was very new, and over confident
supporter:I'm very outgoing now. I had to learn a lot of skills to be this way and I like myself more too. Hahah. I'm old though, 59. You have nothing to lose, consider it a learning opportunity.
supporter:Life is a journey. We all make mistakes in the past.  I think you are very intelligent actually because you thought of the pros and cons.  You just needed a boost.
seeker:Thank you sir, I will definitely try it! You have shared Pure words of wisdom

supporter:I've been a TA for classes before, and even though I sometimes can't do too much to change assignment deadlines, I've always been open to talking to students about their struggles. It helps me to know who to keep an eye on and give extra attention to.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hi, how are you? What would you like to talk about today?
seeker:Hi - I'm sorry. I stepped away from the computer for a moment while waiting...
supporter:That's quite all right. The wait times can be a bit long. How are you?
seeker:Well, my manager has decided that everyone in the office will continue to work from after the pandemic is under control. But I've found myself depressed from working from home all the time.
supporter:Working from home is not what people expected. Many have found themselves isolated. They miss the interaction of the office. How long have you bee working from home?
seeker:For a full year--since March 2020, when the pandemic first started. I was working from home just 1 day per week prior to that, which I liked. But I've found that 5 days per week is much too much. I miss people. :(
supporter:Have you and your co-workers talked to your boss about a hybrid schedule, maybe a couple days a week in the office? That might work.
seeker:That's where it gets awkward. It seems like everyone besides me are super happy that we'll continue working from home. I hesitate to share my feelings because maybe my manager will change her mind, which would be a big bummer for everyone else on the team (seemingly).
supporter:I see. That's a concern. So you feel that if one person goes in to the office, then everyone else will have to? There won't be any flexibility?
seeker:Well, it's possible that my manager will say we can be flexible. But if so, I think I'd end up being the only one in my office working... which would be just as lonely as working from home while throwing away the few perks of working from home, like saving on gas. Plus, I think my company will probably want to repurpose our office space eventually.
seeker:lol, sorry, that was an ugly run-on sentence. :\
supporter:Hm. A bit of a dilemma. Can this situation go on forever though? Maybe the boss will extend the stay-at-home for a while, but when other companies go back to the office, the expectation will be there for all companies.
supporter:Other employees might change their minds bit by bit as well.
seeker:That is indeed a possibility. But my office is in a city that has a whole lot of high-tech companies, which were moving towards doing more work from home even BEFORE the pandemic. So it kind of feels like this might be a "cultural shift" in my area in general. Although there has GOT to be a whole lot of other people who feel like I do. Maybe we should start our own company, lol.
supporter:True. I don't think you are alone. Is there something that you can do to make working at home better for you? More frequent breaks? Better work space?
seeker:That's a good question. My state is still one of the ones that's mostly shut-down. Part of my depression surely stems from the fact that all evening/weekend activities ended a year ago as well.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hi. I’m feeling really depressed lately
supporter:I'm sorry to hear this. Is there something specifically bothering you?
seeker:I just feel like no one I work with really likes me or cares about me
supporter:You don't think people like you or care about you at work? What specifically have they done to make you think this?
seeker:I just feel like no one talks to me and if I try and talk to them they are very dismissive
supporter:I can understand that might make you feel uncomfortable.
seeker:I feel like I go out of my way to help people and I remember their birthdays and I try and be nice to them but no one ever does the same for me
supporter:I have been in many work situations and even social situations where I did not feel as if I fit in, I'm rather an unusual person. I had to learn to not focus so much on BEING accepted. I had to learn what God think of me (he loves me) and try to be kind to all I meet, other centered. That is, I also had to make sure I wasn't being rude or mean.
supporter:I can understand how hurtful that is. Our society isn't as kind as it once was. I find very few people appreciate kindness. However, I can't get caught up in that, it's the way people are. It isn't a reflection of myself.
supporter:I think it is the hardest thing to be more concerned with others than we are with ourselves, it can be lonely.
seeker:I think from now on I’m just going to focus on myself and my family, I’m not gonna out of my way to be nice to my coworkers, I’m just going to treat them as coworkers not as friends and just keep to myself
supporter:I think you can be kind to them, but I think perhaps your expectations are that they reciprocate, and they aren't which hurts. Perhaps be kind without expecting anything in return, and know that God sees your kindness.
seeker:I always feel like you have to be a friend to have friends, but I’m tired of being the only one putting effort in and getting taken advantage of
supporter:I also had this happen, I had no friends and at first I thought it was me, then I realized it was an opportunity for personal growth. Which wasn't easy.
supporter:How do you feel they take advantage?
supporter:Being ignored is one thing, having someone take advantage of you is a different story.
seeker:I just feel like they just expect me to do things for them now and when I do it, it’s no appreciated because they just know I will do it.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello, how are you feeling?
seeker:Tired, very tired!!
supporter:Oh?  How come so tired?
seeker:Because I can't sleep... I don't know what's wrong with me I just lay there awake for hours!
supporter:Oh I have had trouble sleeping before!   Would you like to know what helped me?
seeker:Yes please, I'm desperate, I'll try anything!
supporter:First of all, fixed sleep and wake times.   If you toss and turn for hours, still get up at the same time.   Eventually your body will tire and sleeping will naturally become easier.
seeker:I have to always get up for work so I am sticking to the same routines, I just lie in bed with so many thoughts racing around my head and I just can't get off to sleep
supporter:Second thing I do is I have a wind down routine.   No work past a certain time, no matter what.   Only soft music, pleasant movie, some light reading, and dim the lights.   It slows your body down before sleep.  It will help slow that racing thoughts you are having.
seeker:I did try reading a book last night, but I don't really have lights that I can dim, it's just the one bright light in our room.
supporter:I have had racing thoughts and it used to drive me up the wall!
supporter:Can you buy a lamp?  Even a second hand one if your budget is tight?
seeker:Yeah, it's just so annoying and then I'm so tired and irritable the next day, I find myself snapping at everyone.
supporter:The bright light will keep your mind stimulated.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello how are you?
seeker:I am down feeling depressed
seeker:I feel like the world is crashing down around me
supporter:I have suffered from depression and know how hard that can be
supporter:What seems to have brought it on?
seeker:Thinking about my kids and wanting to be able to hug them and see them they are in a different state
seeker:I have medications I take but I have so many different things going on
supporter:Oh that is hard being separated from family.  Are you unable to t5ravel right now?
seeker:I have PTSD, sleep apnea, and numerous other issues I suffer from as well
supporter:I see
supporter:So are you being followed by a specialist?
seeker:It is hard to travel at the moment I feel I can't trust anyone and don't like to be around a lot of people
seeker:I do see a specialist
supporter:Okay so you are not feeling well enough to travel and see your kids am I right?
seeker:It's even hard for me to go outside
seeker:No I am feeling very down and depressed right now and it is very hard
supporter:That sounds like it would be isolating...are you able to keep in touch with people by telephone, video chat and what not, are you feeling well enough for that?
seeker:My kids call me and facetime me
supporter:I know when I am depressed I don't want to see or talk to anyone...
seeker:My oldest son texts me a lot so I am thankful for that
supporter:Oh I'm so glad you are in touch in that way, do you find them supportive?
seeker:My kids make me happy to talk to but usually I don't feel like seeing anyone
supporter:Is there any way they can come and visit you?
seeker:I don't even know how to describe how I feel to people sometimes
seeker:I hope they will be coming soon when my youngest son gets out of school
supporter:It sounds like you are feeling overwhelmed right now.
seeker:My mood seems to go up and down but mostly stays down I don't like going anywhere
supporter:Is there anyone else besides your specialist and your kids that you can reach out to for support in your community, even if it's just by pone?
seeker:That makes me feel so bad too because I never used to be this way
seeker:I am remarried and my wife tries to help as much as possible
supporter:And you won't feel this way forever, it will pass, know that, even if it does not feel like it, it will.  It can be hard to see any light at the end of the tunnel when we are depressed.
seeker:I live close to my sister as well but it is still difficult for me to even talk a lot to them
supporter:Oh that's great you have a supportive wife!
seeker:I feel like I don't have anyone sometimes and she is supportive but I just get to feeling down and shutdown
supporter:In my community we have mental health programs, I am actually doing some via zoom, do you know if there is anything like that you can access?
seeker:I shutdown from everything and feel worthless sometimes
supporter:I understand that shut down feeling....I close right up when I am down
seeker:I hate to feel like that but I feel there is nothing I can do sometimes
supporter:Feeling worthless, uninterested in going out, those are symptoms of depression, they will pass
seeker:I don't find fun in things I used to do that was fun
seeker:I feel so separated from people my parents both are gone now too
supporter:Lack of interest in things is also a symptom of depression.   Once your depression lifts it will come back.   I'll tell you what helped me when I was depresed...
seeker:My dad passed away 24 years ago and my mom passed away last easter too
seeker:what helped you?
supporter:I was taught to make very small goals.  For example, I found it hard to go out for a walk, even though I knew it would help my depression. (Exercise has been shown to be as effective as antidpressants)  So I was told, just walk around the block.  If that's too much, walk to the corner.   If that's too much, walk to the end f the driveway.  If that's too much, step outside.   If that's too much, put your shoes on.   Baby steps.

seeker:Hi I'm experiencing a lot of anxiety and depression because of constant severe back pain.
supporter:when did this start?
seeker:About eight years ago.
supporter:i see. have you sought out any medical help with the back pain?
seeker:Yes, I was supposed to have surgery for it, but it has been cancelled because the hospitals are full due to the coronavirus.
supporter:yeah, this pandemic has thrown a wrench into many people's plans, but hopefully things will ease up soon.
seeker:I hope so too, but it looks like it's going to be a long time.
supporter:it is a bit daunting when we see the number of infections increasing and people getting sick, but i think it will just be a matter of time before things get better. and hopefully a vaccine will help with the hospitalizations
seeker:Hopefully, but how to deal with it in the mean time?
supporter:i think you're already taking a step in the right direction by talking to me about your anxiety and depression. i'm amazed that you've been able to just deal with it for 8 years
supporter:i've had friends who suffered from anxiety and depression, and i've noticed that just talking things through can sometimes help a lot
seeker:It's been very hard,  I've also had to take care of my mother in that time period, but she sadly passed away last march, possibly from the virus and I've been having a hard time processing that grief.
supporter:i'm very sorry to hear about your mother's passing, and a significant loss like that can take some time to  process
supporter:from my experience, it really helps just to open up to someone about the things that are on your mind. even a journal can help. if you have someone who can lend an ear to listen and a shoulder to cry on, spending some time with them can help you get your feelings out and might give you a sense of relief
seeker:That's true, I know many are suffering so much right now and many people have also lost their loved ones. It makes the isolation all the harder trying to handle the grief. It does help to talk, thank you. Do you have any suggestions on how to handle the anxiety?
supporter:personally, i find that hobbies are great for getting your mind off things and keeping yourself occupied means that your mind doesn't wander into dark thoughts
seeker:That is good advice, I will try to stay busier. Also, do you know of any support groups online that might be helpful?
supporter:just from this limited conversation, it sounds like you're an amazing person and i sincerely commend you for seeking help here and pushing yourself to cope with you loss and pain. i really wish there was more i could do to help but i believe in you ;)

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:How do you become happy? How do you find something worth living for?
supporter:Hi, I think there are a lot of ways to become happy and to find something worthy living for. Let's start with things that interest you. What do you like doing for fun?
seeker:I don't really know anymore, nothing makes me happy these days.
seeker:I used to like reading a lot but it's become a chore.
supporter:And what kinds of things did you like to read?
seeker:Mostly fiction books. Fantasy, historical novels, contemporary fiction, anything really.
supporter:That's really great! I used to struggle with finding joy in reading as well. I was a graduate student at the time so I was mostly reading research papers.
seeker:Do you like reading again? What helped?
supporter:Have you tried picking up a new hobby? Something you have always thought might be fun but haven't ever tried because of lack of time or energy?
seeker:I wanted to try rock climbing, but I don't know. I'm not really in the best shape.
supporter:I do like reading now. I took some time after school to take care of my mental health by going on walks and being in nature. Overtime, I started to pick up books again. I've found I really like true crime and autobiographies the best
seeker:I feel like people will just make fun of me.
supporter:Rock climbing is so fun! Have you tried taking a beginners course? I started there. I was very nervous I would be made fun of, but found that it was a really supportive community.
seeker:I guess I can give it a try.
seeker:But I don't know if it will be enough.
supporter:You might find it's just the community of people that you need right now. From my experience, they were all super friendly and open to helping me along the way.
seeker:I guess you're right. I tend to get caught up in my own thoughts, which never have anything good to say about me.
supporter:Just from chatting with you, you seem like such a nice person. I don't think anyone would have mean things to say about you.
seeker:That's kind of you to say.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello there. Is there anything bothering you that you'd like to talk about at the moment?
seeker:Hi. Yes, I'm having a hard time because last year my dad died a few days after Christmas.
supporter:Oh I am so sorry! Dealing with bereavement is hard at any time but at this time of year I think that it is even worse.
seeker:When people ask about Christmas plans, I don't want to depress everyone. But I can't pretend everything's okay.
supporter:So you feel as though you have to avoid people because you do not want to make them feel bad that you are feeling bad?
seeker:I don't know... I know my friends would be supportive. But then I feel like it's selfish of me to bring people down, when this whole year has been a downer for so many of us.
supporter:Well let me ask you - if the situation were reversed, would you feel that a close friend was bringing you down if they talked about their bereavement?
seeker:Maybe, but I wouldn't mind that.
supporter:Well, perhaps your friends would not mind you confiding in them either? That is what good friends are for, ultimately.
seeker:Another thing is that my mom had died in January, the same year. So everyone has already dealt with me grieving all year. I don't want to just be associated with sadness for everyone.
supporter:I am really sorry about that - that is a seriously rough thing to have had to deal with. Do you have siblings and if so could you perhaps talk with them?
seeker:I have a brother, but his wife is really terrible, and they are very close. He and I text some, and I try to keep that up. He doesn't need me the way I need him...
supporter:What about some sort of professional therapy? There are some organisations out there that will provide a certain number of sessions for free
seeker:Hmm, I didn't know that. I'm on a waiting list for a therapist through my medical insurance. I live in sort of rural Oregon, but maybe I could get help by text or video...
supporter:That is a good idea, especially at this time when it's probably not a good idea to see too many new people in person. Could you call your doctor and ask them?
seeker:The issue is finding someone you click with. I think that's hard. I'm not sure my doctor could do much for me - she's already got me on the waiting list for therapy through her organization.
supporter:Have you tried searching online? I have personally found some useful groups that have helped me deal with the mental health issues that I have.
seeker:If it wasn't for COVID, I'd probably look into support groups...
seeker:Oh yeah? Can you recommend anywhere to start?
supporter:There are plenty available online where you would not need to see anyone in person. Try googling for support groups in your local area?
supporter:I'd really recommend doing that, it could help you a lot! I wish you all the best and hope that 2021 is a better year for you.
seeker:Okay. I also just moved to a new state, and don't really know anyone yet. It's a hard time for making new connections.
seeker:Thank you - best wishes to you, too!

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello, how are you doing today?
seeker:Not too bad, really. Just kinda pissed.
supporter:Sorry to hear you're upset. Want to share why you're feeling that way?
seeker:Sure, I guess "venting" is pretty much all I have that I can do at this point.
supporter:Do you feel like you can't take any actions in the situation?
seeker:Long story short - at work, a new boss pulled all the leadership OUT of the jobs they were hired for (some more than 12 years ago - so they have lots of experience) and shuffled them all around to new jobs - all that is except the 5 oldest employees - they got moved into "non-positions". No longer supervising anyone, only doing grunt work, etc. It ticks me off and there's nothing I can do about it.
seeker:I'm working on a *possible* action - RETIREMENT from this job. Only problem is - bad time to be doing that; pressure to keep my income up until my daughter graduates college, etc.
supporter:That sounds frustrating, especially if you're one of the employees affected and when the new boss doesn't seem to know what he/she is doing with the reorganization.
supporter:That's positive, though, that you at least have a strategy in mind with retirement, even if this may not be the best time right now.
seeker:She has a "plan", I guess, but it isn't being articulated that well, and these actions are demonstrating poor "people management" and seem to be both confusing lots of folks, and professionally insulting many others. Oh, and by the way, things are running WORSE than they were before, but it's being blamed on COVID
seeker:Problem with the "retirement strategy" is that it means going out on a limb with no job with the holidays coming up, and with COVID with no end in sight. SO, just "muddling through" the days these days, hoping better times are ahead.
supporter:It sounds like you are not the only worker who is seriously questioning the changes being made.
seeker:Oh, no. 1 person outright quit immediately. 1 other has retired already. 1 more I know is retiring by New Years. Others are more "stuck", as they just CAN'T afford to quit OR retire. So, yeah, us "old folk" are not "happy campers"
supporter:Wow! From what you've said, it sounds like your coworkers feel much as you do about the changes.
seeker:Yep. We are sort of our own "support group", but since we are all 100% teleworking these days, we don't "see" each other, though we try to touch base through phone calls at least once a week.
supporter:That must be tough, but it must help to at least commiserate through the phone calls and be able to relate to each other.
seeker:Yep. Best I can hope for at this point. If I find another job to transition to, that would improve things. Until then, gotta just "keep on keeping on"
supporter:My former spouse works for a company that has moved him to departments he needed to retrain to work in, and he is considering looking for a different job, maybe after COVID is outta here.
supporter:It sounds like you're determined to stay as positive as possible while considering other options, such as a new job. Doing something about it like this must feel a little better.
seeker:As good as it can. Thanks for your time and commiseration.
supporter:You're welcome! I also think that's wise to hold off on retirement until your daughter is through college. My oldest is ready for college and I don't feel ready to leave work, either.
seeker:Yep, and she's actually a senior, so she'll graduate in May. But I gotta keep my motivation up until then. ;)

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello. How are you tonight?
seeker:I'm hanging in there. I'm in a funk.
supporter:I'm sorry to hear things aren't going to well. What's the problem in a nutshell?
seeker:I split with my girlfriend after 5 years together last month/
supporter:Breakups can be hard, I can understand your frustration. Five years is a long time to have a relationship and then end.
seeker:I caught her cheating on me.
supporter:I'm sorry to hear that. That's hard to forgive and move on from that.
seeker:I'm trying to just move on but I feel so insulted. I'm mad then sad back and forth, over and over.
supporter:I find that when I have a very painful situation, I try to only thing about it for a certain amount of time. Then I make a list of things to do so I can be occupied to not think about it.
seeker:Yes, but my whole life was upended. My living situation, my friend circle is broken up over this. I don't know how to move on. Any suggestions?
supporter:Getting over a breakup will take time? Have you ever heard of DABDA? Denial (I can't believe this happened!) Anger (we all know that) Bargaining (If only I had done that, or if only - trying to make it FEEL better by imagining other scenarios - doesn't really work) Depression - sadness, then Acceptance -- we go in and out of these emotions and sometimes it can make us feel crazy, but all of them are normal in varying degrees and we don't know when they will happen.
seeker:No, but those sound like the typical stages of grief. I guess I'm in anger. I have no interest in barbagining.
supporter:I would make a list of things you have always wanted to do and then just BRAINSTORM any idea, no idea is too out there -- learn to ice skate, learn to play the ukulele, sign up for dance lessons, join the gym, go to a singles group at church, visit the elderly, volunteer somewhere.
seeker:I think I need to focus on exercise. Just get my body and mind healthy and full of energy. What do you think?
supporter:I also find it helpful not only to limit how much I dwell on my pain, but make sure I reach out to help someone else. I will tell you, that is the secret to happiness. Maybe help a neighbor with groceries or hanging lights. Old people (me) love help, bake something or call your aunt or uncle.
seeker:True, but it's hard not to dwell. It's not like I have a choice. It overcomes me.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Good afternoon!  What can I help you with today?
seeker:Hello every since I lost my job I have felt sad and useless
supporter:That is an extremely tough situation to go through, I'm sorry to hear that.
seeker:Application after application I get rejected, it makes it hard to even fill out more
supporter:Yes, job applications can feel particularly demeaning to complete.  Personally, I get frustrated with all the repetition and then repetitive rejection.  It seems like I had no value.
supporter:But you have to consider that there are dozens of different reasons why you don't get selected for a job, and quite a few of them have nothing to do with you , either as a person or as an employee.
seeker:It feels good someone else knows how frustrating and what a cycle it creates but I am also sorry that you do know how it is also.
seeker:Thank you for that, it seems most of the jobs I am applying for I am over qualified for which doesn't make sense to me and makes me think it is something personal about me.
supporter:No, don't think that.  I know of several employers that have actually said they don't want employees smarter than them.  It requires more money and more management, and quite a few people are very happy to not do either of those things for ostensibly higher quality workforce.
supporter:On an actionable level, have you been getting blocked at the application point or the interviewing point?
seeker:Hopefully I find an employer that sees a quality workforce over other things, its getting pretty discouraging
seeker:I seem to be getting blocked at application level for employment, it seems my skills are mostly being put out to contract work now, which is not something I am familiar with.
supporter:I see.  Maybe there are some qualification programs in your local area, or maybe at the local university or college where you could take classes?  There is a career development center at my local university that is open to everyone, maybe you could see if they would review your resume and give you some objective feedback?  Students love a good live subject :-)
seeker:Wow I have never thought about that! That sounds awesome and like it would be great help, also trying something new would feel nice instead of filing the same stuff into applications!
supporter:You should explore what resources your city/county/province may offer for job seekers.  It is in the best interest of almost every community that its members have have jobs and feel useful, so you may find some valuable information and maybe some connections.
supporter:Oh!  And what I always tell everyone who is looking for a job:  Apply UP!  Don't ever think is something above your level.  Apply UP!  They may admire your temerity and invite you for an interview just to see who you think you are :-)
seeker:My spirits are going up just having this conversation and looking forward to the community outreach. Hopefully it helps lift this gloom that has been over me for months. I loved my previous job but due to bad management it was taking a toll on everyone employed.
supporter:I am glad to hear you are feeling a little better!  Yes, bad management is so toxic.  Even with great coworkers in a job you love, horrible management can ruin it quickly.

Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hi there, how are you feeling today?
seeker:Hi. I don't know... sort of down. Sort of empty... How about you?
supporter:I am feeling a bit the same. Is there something specific that you'd like to talk about?
seeker:Well, I moved to a new state - feeling pretty alone.
supporter:Do you not know anyone else there?
seeker:No, not really. I inherited some money, because both of my parents died last year. So I bought a house I love, in a tiny town...
supporter:Do you think it would benefit you to join some groups or societies where you would meet new people?
supporter:If you feel a little out of your depth, that is perfectly normal at this stage!
seeker:Yes, probably. But of course it's a weird time for that, with COVID...
supporter:Yes of course. So you feel that you cannot meet new people due to the pandemic?
seeker:Well, I didn't really do that much before COVID. But everything's changed in my life. I thought I could make a new start.
supporter:I understand that this is a bad time to be making a new start but please believe me, I think that things will get better
seeker:I feel like I know what the right things to do are, but nothing sounds fun. I feel like I'm just trying to force myself to do the things I should want to do.
supporter:It sounds to me like you might be suffering from depression. A lot of the population have this problem! Do you think that this might be the case?
seeker:It's not that I thought money would buy me happiness, but it is strange that now that I could do almost anything, I really can't think of anything I want to do.
supporter:That definitely sounds like depression to me. Can I suggest that you talk to your doctor?
seeker:I definitely have depression. I can try taking meds again, I should probalby try counseling... I did start going to a doctor, at least
supporter:So you have insight into your condition at least ...  that is a very positive thing!
seeker:I know it makes sense to try that, since it does help some people. But I just feel like, I know what they're going to say. I already know what I should do. I just don't do it.
supporter:What is it that you feel that you should be doing? Please do not put too much pressure on yourself!
seeker:It's like I'm just so lazy... I don't do anything.  I could honestly just stay in bed and read and sleep all day and night.
supporter:I understand how that feels. I often feel the same way myself, especially now (and at this time of year). Please do not feel bad about it.
seeker:I'm not suicidal at all, but I would be totally fine with a big meteor taking us all out tomorrow. I feel like I gave it a shot, I'm sort of ready to be done. I find myself feeling jealous of very old people...

seeker:He has, and yes I've told him, he just dismisses it, thinks it's funny that I get jealous
supporter:I understand your frustration, it's upsetting when they dismiss what you say even though you have been friends for so long.
seeker:Thanks.
supporter:What I would recommend in this case is, spend more time with other friends who appreciate you. You also need to tell Rick your honest thought, don't beat around the bush but let him know you're serious
seeker:That's good advice! Thanks. I wonder how I can get through to him to really let him know I'm serious. Ideas?
supporter:I have been in the same situation myself, what I usually do is sit down with them and start the conversation in a serious mood. Explain everything I need to say and tell them that I mean every word. If they don't seem to accept and change, I keep my distance from them

supporter:Yes. Be not too harsh at first. I would say to give him 1 more chance. If he still doesn't respect your words, it's the best for both to say it clearly.

seeker:Suggestions welcome! :)
supporter:You have the right mindset! Practice before talking will help you deliver your thoughts better.

supporter:I would start with something along the line "Look, I  know we have had this conversation many times. However, i feel as though you never take me seriously. I want to say this one last time...."
seeker:That's perfect. Copying that down right now!
seeker:Seriously!
supporter:Getting emotional is totally fine, that's why you need practice
