prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello how are you?
seeker:I am down feeling depressed
seeker:I feel like the world is crashing down around me
supporter:I have suffered from depression and know how hard that can be
supporter:What seems to have brought it on?
seeker:Thinking about my kids and wanting to be able to hug them and see them they are in a different state
seeker:I have medications I take but I have so many different things going on
supporter:Oh that is hard being separated from family.  Are you unable to t5ravel right now?
seeker:I have PTSD, sleep apnea, and numerous other issues I suffer from as well
supporter:I see
supporter:So are you being followed by a specialist?
seeker:It is hard to travel at the moment I feel I can't trust anyone and don't like to be around a lot of people
seeker:I do see a specialist
supporter:Okay so you are not feeling well enough to travel and see your kids am I right?
seeker:It's even hard for me to go outside
seeker:No I am feeling very down and depressed right now and it is very hard
supporter:That sounds like it would be isolating...are you able to keep in touch with people by telephone, video chat and what not, are you feeling well enough for that?
seeker:My kids call me and facetime me
supporter:I know when I am depressed I don't want to see or talk to anyone...
seeker:My oldest son texts me a lot so I am thankful for that
supporter:Oh I'm so glad you are in touch in that way, do you find them supportive?
seeker:My kids make me happy to talk to but usually I don't feel like seeing anyone
supporter:Is there any way they can come and visit you?
seeker:I don't even know how to describe how I feel to people sometimes
seeker:I hope they will be coming soon when my youngest son gets out of school
supporter:It sounds like you are feeling overwhelmed right now.
seeker:My mood seems to go up and down but mostly stays down I don't like going anywhere
supporter:Is there anyone else besides your specialist and your kids that you can reach out to for support in your community, even if it's just by pone?
seeker:That makes me feel so bad too because I never used to be this way
seeker:I am remarried and my wife tries to help as much as possible
supporter:And you won't feel this way forever, it will pass, know that, even if it does not feel like it, it will.  It can be hard to see any light at the end of the tunnel when we are depressed.
seeker:I live close to my sister as well but it is still difficult for me to even talk a lot to them
supporter:Oh that's great you have a supportive wife!
seeker:I feel like I don't have anyone sometimes and she is supportive but I just get to feeling down and shutdown
supporter:In my community we have mental health programs, I am actually doing some via zoom, do you know if there is anything like that you can access?
seeker:I shutdown from everything and feel worthless sometimes
supporter:I understand that shut down feeling....I close right up when I am down
seeker:I hate to feel like that but I feel there is nothing I can do sometimes
supporter:Feeling worthless, uninterested in going out, those are symptoms of depression, they will pass
seeker:I don't find fun in things I used to do that was fun
seeker:I feel so separated from people my parents both are gone now too
supporter:Lack of interest in things is also a symptom of depression.   Once your depression lifts it will come back.   I'll tell you what helped me when I was depresed...
seeker:My dad passed away 24 years ago and my mom passed away last easter too
seeker:what helped you?
supporter:I was taught to make very small goals.  For example, I found it hard to go out for a walk, even though I knew it would help my depression. (Exercise has been shown to be as effective as antidpressants)  So I was told, just walk around the block.  If that's too much, walk to the corner.   If that's too much, walk to the end f the driveway.  If that's too much, step outside.   If that's too much, put your shoes on.   Baby steps.
supporter:And whatever small step you manage to acheive, celebrate it and reward yourself.
seeker:I would like to know because I don't like the feeling of depression and anxiety not being able to sleep
supporter:Ultimately, my last depression it was getting my covid shot that helped most....lifted a bunch of fear and anxiety and restored my hope.
supporter:Does your specialist know you are this down?
seeker:I try to go out and walk my wife likes to go outside so I try to do that but I still feel so down and I don't like how I feel I have become I get angry all the time too I feel like
seeker:Yes my specialist knows and I have appointments with them more often
supporter:And losing your mum last Easter, you are probably still dealing with grief on top of everything else.   My parents are gone too, grief can be a long process.  Grief is tough.  That will get easier with time.
seeker:My meds I take have been increased and I hate to just take meds to try to help
supporter:The thing is though, depression is an illness.   Would you take meds for another sort of illness, something physical?
seeker:It has been 24 years since my dad has passed away and he was my best friend and I still hurt everyday
supporter:That is hard, I'm sorry you are hurting
supporter:Have you tried writing down your thoughts and feelings in a journal?
seeker:I know and I try to get out but after I retired from military I still have thoughts about all that I seen there too and I hate that
supporter:okay so the PTSD is related to time in the military?
seeker:I don't like to tell everyone about that because I feel like I am bringing everyone down saying that too
seeker:Yes the PTSD is from the military time
supporter:Are there any veterans groups in your area that help with that?
supporter:Maybe connecting with others "in the same boat" would help
seeker:I am not sure but I don't like to be in big groups either
supporter:Or maybe there is a way online you could do that, virtual meetings, since you find it hard to get out.   Could you handle a zoom group meeting?
seeker:I get easily startled now too when I am outside I always feel like someone is coming close to me and no one is there
supporter:I attend zoom group meetings for my mental health.  They have helped.
seeker:I am not sure about that I feel ashamed a lot too about the way I feel
supporter:You are going through a lot, but you are stronger than you feel, I know you can get through this.   Things will get easier.
seeker:I don't think people should feel the way I do and I don't understand my feelings either
supporter:Have you done any research online about PTSD....perhaps your veteran organization has resources on their website
seeker:I truly hope so because I feel like I am against a wall sometimes too with my thoughts and feelings
supporter:That is so hard, I hear you
seeker:I have not done a lot of research but I need to try that
supporter:Research is something solitary you can do
seeker:I feel like I am complaining to people too and that bothers me too because I am not
supporter:Whereabouts do you live?
seeker:I live in southern Tennessee
supporter:Well you are being honest.  Some people will be able to handle that, some won't, but either way it takes courage to communicate how badly you feel.
seeker:I am with the VA now they get all my appointments for me
seeker:I truly feel like my back is against the wall and I have never been that way I used to have fun
supporter:ok good.   I see online that Tennessee Dept of Veterans lists some mental health resources
seeker:I go to see one of my specialists tomorrow actually VA
supporter:You will have fun again.   Your feelings are due to depression, you will get through it, it will lift.
seeker:I really appreciate you listening to me
seeker:You are very kind to listen and try to make things better
supporter:Good.   Be honest and open with your specialist please?  That's important.   It's a pleasure listening to you, you're welcome
seeker:I hope you are right and someday these feelings do go
supporter:Aw thank you for the compliment
seeker:I hope you have a great rest of your day and thank you so much for the kindness
supporter:Honestly, I have been ill with depression several times, and have felt hopeless...and it always lifted
supporter:You're so welcome.   Feel better soon.
seeker:Thank you

supporter:Hello, you there?

supporter:Good! How are you today?
seeker:I'm doing ok. Feeling kinda stuck at the moment though. Struggling with everything happening around me without me
supporter:You feel left out out. Is that what you're saying?
seeker:Maybe not so much left out but moreso left behind. I really feel like everyone else is where they're supposed to be in life and I'm just floundering here without a clue what to do next. I'm just so used to being a mom that now that my son is getting mroe independent, I really feel like when I try to look at myself, I don't see a path to things working out
supporter:I see and there was a time I felt lost or not needed too. What is it you would like to do with your life?
seeker:I really have no idea. I've been depressed for a really long time. I don't find joy in the things I used to so I don't even know what I like to do.
supporter:The best way to begin to solve a problem is recognizing there's a problem in the first place. Give yourself some credit because recognize there is a problem. Do you have friends who are mothers too and who are having some of the same issues as yourself?

supporter:I see. You know if you get a mirror and look in it you'll see you are a natural leader. Here's the proof; You realized there's a problem. 2. You reached out for help. 3. supporter:That's understandable. Most parents feel like you do so you're not alone. When I feel closed off I write. I make up stories where I'm always the heroe. Don't laugh. I always overcome some issue. I also write letters just to get out what I'm feeling. It helps and you should try it. Start a diary or write letters to your son so you can share them with him one . Are these activities you might like to try?

supporter:Hello, how are we doing today?
seeker:Hi.  I'm doing fine.  Just feeling a bit anxious.

seeker:Well, I am retired, but in need of extra income to meet my financial obligations.  It is very difficult for me, however, to wear a mask for longer than a few moments.  Due to the mandates in my area, I would be required to wear a mask.
supporter:Well, have you tried online platforms like MTurk?
supporter:It can be bit tough to get into in the beginning, but with a decent amount of work and determination it might be able to help with your monetary problems.
seeker:That is what I am currently doing, and it is helping some.  I have increased the time I work on there, so that will help some.  I would love a second source as well, however...just so I could really save some.
supporter:I hear you on that. I am disabled and the extra income helps a lot for my family. Unfortunately until the pandemic ends a part time job might not be in your best interest for now. Ebay flipping takes some time to get into as well but could help.
seeker:Yes, I have thought of that, actually.  I have quite a few items I would love to sell.  I have never done it, though, so need to research how to ship items, etc.
supporter:Its actually very easy now. You can print out the slips at home and they tell you how much it will be. I have done it a few times, the last time was only a couple months a go.
seeker:Well, I will definitely have to check that out.  It would serve two purposes : decluttering and making money.  I think I got anxious last week when I had a tire go flat and took my car in to get it fixed.  I found out I need all new tires and new brakes.  Not easy on a fixed income.  Plus I am widowed.
supporter:I am sorry for that. Yea having a nest egg is ideal, but i know how hard it can be. I think with the extra cash and space it may be a big help to those anxiety issues. Do you drive a lot as it is now?
seeker:I actually don't. Only to the grocery store, or to visit my daughter who lives about 20  minutes away.
supporter:Well at least you are not putting to much wear on them now. Have you checked with local governments for assistance? Even with things like medication?

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Good morning!  What can I help you with today?
seeker:Hi, i've been feeling really depressed lately and I'd like to talk to someone about it
supporter:That is very understandable.  Depression is tough to deal with.
supporter:Do you have specific things that are causing you sadness right now or is it an overall feeling of being sad?
seeker:It's a bit of everything. I've recently lost my job and I'm just really worried about how my bills are going to get paid. I feel so tired, you know?
supporter:I totally understand.  Losing your job is a very rough thing to go through, I'm sorry that happened to you.  Feeling constantly at red alert is taxing both mentally and physically.
supporter:There is a concept called Maslow's hierarchy of needs, and sometimes I find it useful to think about if my needs are being met, and which is lacking.  Which is to say, obviously financial security is your primary need at the moment, but there are other needs you must attend to as well, including your physical comforts.
supporter:In times of great stress and upheaval, there is only so much you can do.  The rest is worry, a hamster running in a wheel, a huge output of energy that does nothing at all.
seeker:Yeah that makes sense but I've spent so much time thinking about my finances that I've sort of burned myself out
seeker:Like I have no energy even to be thankful for the other little stuff
supporter:That makes sense.  You sound emotionally exhausted.
seeker:Definitely, I feel like I could sleep forever but with my kids to worry about I don't have that option
supporter:Gratitude is one of those things, I've found, that is self-perpetuating.  Even if you begin by doing it robotically, eventually your mind and heart will want to be more sincerely grateful.  I have in the past challenged myself to find five things to be grateful for in the morning and write them down.  Whether those things are "I have hot coffee and electricity" or "I won $1000 for free", they will begin to start a small fire of joy.
seeker:Messages could work, I could stick them around and I guess they coudl help not just me but my little ones too because I'm sure my moods been affecting them as well
supporter:That sounds like a great idea!  It sounds like you care a lot about your kids, I bet it's easy for you to be grateful for them :-)
supporter:And I know that they are grateful for you, whether they are able to articulate that or not
seeker:Absolutely the little terrors are the reason I get up in the morning. I can't let them down, you know
seeker:Their dad's not arpund so its just us
seeker:I'm all they've got
supporter:Well that is an enormous amount of responsibility that has been placed upon your shoulders, but your attitude seems extremely pleasant and positive.  It does not sound easy, but you should make sure you build in some time for yourself if you can.
seeker:I'm going to try, the messages idea is a really good one so I think I'll give that a try. I mean I am grateful for my kids and I guess things could be worse I do still have some savings left and I can always try to get another job
supporter:You definitely have options, but your situation is still tough, and you deserve relief where you can get it.
seeker:I'll keep that in mind but thank you for taking the time to let me get things off my chest
seeker:It really helps
supporter:Of course, I am happy if I was able to help.  You have a good heart and love your kids, you stay strong, you can do this :-)
seeker:Thank you and I'll be trying! I hope you have awesome day and thanks again

s I used to.

supporter:Hello
seeker:Hi there I was hoping you can help me.
supporter:Sure. What can I help you with?
seeker:Well you see I am heartbroken and I can't seem to move on from a previous relationship, and its been over two years. Do you have any advice?
supporter:I’m understand how hard ending a relationship can be.
supporter:What do you find is the hardest thing for you each day. That is, where do you find it hardest to move on?
seeker:Well I would say mentally because I frequently think about her and constantly have memories throughout the day. Also when i hear a certain song or see a restaurant it makes me think of her.
supporter:Memories are a blessing and a curse. Are the memories and thought you are  having positive or negative?
seeker:They are a mix of both because at one point they were positive and now when I think about it, it brings me down in a negative way.
seeker:What have you done in the past to help you move on from a break up?
supporter:It’s hard when we have various emotions. These memories being more negative are hard to cope with. In my experience, if I rethink memories regarding relationships which tend to bring me down in way that is a learning experience, I feel more empowered.
seeker:Yeah I agree that's what I have been doing too, and it's nice to know that you do the same.
supporter:In my past I have been able to try and look at each  relationship as a chance to grow. To figure out what worked with that person and what didn’t. I have them used this as a tool for the future.
seeker:That's a good way to look at it.
supporter:You are making good steps to rethink the situations. Is there anything else contributing to the heat rack you still feel?
supporter:Heartbreak
seeker:Well I have also not met anyone since and fear that I will not fall in love again.
supporter:That is difficult. I understand how it feels to be lonely. Something I’ve done when I’ve felt that way was to learn to fall in love with myself. I like to do self care and make time for things I might not have time for if I were in a relationship.
seeker:hmm interesting I have never thought about falling in love with myself..maybe I will give it a try. Thanks.
supporter:It’s so important to love yourself. Self love breeds confidence and confidence is not only attractive, but powerful in so many ways
seeker:I appreciate the feedback and support, you have helped me take the next step to move on with my life.

seeker:And it's just stressful and depressig
supporter:Drastic changes in our life plans can feel very upsetting and looking for a job in these times is ridiculous.
seeker:Yes, it really is
supporter:What made you feel the need to drop out of graduate school?
seeker:I wasn't finding the program challenging or interesting or a life course I was sure I wanted to go down anymore
seeker:The only jobs I really can do with biology are lab jobs, which are somewhat boring. There are some others, but not many
supporter:I understand that and that was a really brave choice to make before you cornered yourself into a degree that wouldn't benefit your future paths.
seeker:Yea, I think that's true. Other people say that I am a quitter
seeker:They say I quit everything
supporter:Have you gone and smoke to your local job centers? They can often times find suitable jobs or even creative suggestions that can utilize your skills and even grown them.

supporter:Refusing to finish something that does not benefit your end goal isn't quitting its merely switching strategies to your personal end goal

seeker:I suppose, I'm just getting older and wish I had better, more stable options available to me. All this education hasn't really left with me many hard skills, I feel
supporter:I am from North Carolina and in every city there are job centers, you can look them up by that title, they have people there who can help you find work based on your personality and skills. as well helping with resumes, interveiws, computers, all kinds of things.
seeker:Interesting. I guess I can look into that. I am from Ohio. That's not bad advice.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hi, how are you? What would you like to discuss today?
seeker:Hello my name is Marie
seeker:I have a lot of depression
seeker:I feel like I'm always hurting
supporter:Hi, Marie. You are dealing with depression. I'm sorry to hear that.
seeker:I have low energy most of the time except for when I'm working
supporter:What is it about work that gets you going?
seeker:My job is fast paced I work for a call center working from home
supporter:You spend a lot of your day talking and interacting with people. Do you enjoy the work?
seeker:I'm always taking one call after the other and barely got time to think about my problems I'm dealing with
seeker:I enjoy my job
supporter:The work distracts you from your problems but it does not give you time to address them.
seeker:I feel like I get to help alot of people
seeker:it distracts me from my problems exactly
supporter:I'm sure you do! Phone support requires a lot of patient explanation. That is challenging for many people.
seeker:I'm actually one of the best at my job
seeker:I wish I was that good with myself personally
supporter:I'm glad you have found success and fulfillment at your work.
seeker:Thank you
supporter:If your job is good for you, what do you think makes you feel depressed then?
seeker:I don't know what I'm going to myself when I'm not working
seeker:I feel hopeless about many things
supporter:Exercise? Reading? School? Friends?
supporter:Hopelessness might be something that you have learned because you have expectations.
supporter:Do you feel that there has to be some sort of result? Progress? Improvement?
seeker:trying to lose weight, trying to void getting diabetes, having better conversation with boyfriend , convince him to spend more time with me instead of work buddies after work hours, want to finish college, being able to buy a house, improving my credit, convincing my dad and brother to get mental help
supporter:If you didn't do any of those things ever, how would you feel about yourself?
seeker:having a more active lifestyle , 
making new friends
seeker:those are things I need to accomplish
supporter:Now imagine you achieve all of those things, and you do so in spectacular fashion. Would you be happy? Or would you find another reason to feel hopeless?
seeker:I believe those are the things that have been bothering me for a long time
seeker:not being able to accomplish those things makes me feel hopeless
seeker:frustrated
seeker:feel like I'm meaningless to thers
supporter:It's important to remember that you choose what goals to pursue. You decide the criteria for success and failure. You are the final arbiter of your life.
seeker:those are all goals in my life that I need to reach
seeker:I just don't know how most of the time
supporter:I understand. We all have goals. Goals can be helpful. But ask yourself why you chose those particular goals.
seeker:I feel like I can't get guidance anywhere
seeker:those are goals that when I accomplish them it will make me feel better
supporter:It sounds like you need someone to tell you what to do, or to give you permission to do what you want to do.
seeker:if I accomplish them it will feel like there was improvement
seeker:probably I've been used to my dad telling me what to do for a long time
seeker:I lack self motivation
supporter:If you need permission, I hereby grant you permission to pursue what is meaningful to you.
supporter:You gave me a list of things that you want to achieve. Pick one.
seeker:I want to do
 all those
seeker:I'm not sure what should I do first
supporter:I understand. Which one is more important. Which is the one you can do right away? Also: which one do you really *not* want to do?
seeker:I feel like all those goals will take some time
seeker:can't be accomplish right away
supporter:Of course. Anything worthwhile takes time.
seeker:I need to stay on top of those goals but I feel like I get side tracked
supporter:You feel compelled to pursue these goals. Why? If you don't, what is the worst that could happen? What if you only pursued one goal?
seeker:pursuing only one of these will not be enough to make me happy I will keep thinking about the goals I need to accomplish
supporter:You need to readjust your expectations, which are causing you to feel unhappy.
seeker:is there a technique that you can suggest I follow to feel self motivated and keep my goals organized and in check
seeker:I will feel successful after completing most of these goals
supporter:Pick a small action, like making your bed. Establish a habit of doing it daily. It will be easy to build on that success, but you might first establish a habit.
seeker:yeah sometimes I don't make the bed I wait to see if my boyfriends makes it sometimes
seeker:sometimes I do make the bed
seeker:it's not that bad doing that
supporter:Make the bed every day. Then pick another small goal.
seeker:I actually feel good about my self after making the bed
seeker:procrastination seems to get the best of me
seeker:I wish I made the bed more often
supporter:That is evidence that you should continue that behavior.
seeker:that sounds weird
seeker:not what you said I referring to what I said I think it was weird
seeker:right?
seeker:maybe you're right I need to make it a habit
supporter:What do you think sounds weird?
seeker:I need to make the bed more often since it makes me feel good after making it
supporter:That is not weird at all.
seeker:oh okay thanks

seeker:Potentially yes but the position above me is not really like for me and I don't like the reporting line. I think I fancy a change but not quite sure how to tackle it. I need the income so can't just leave but also need to do something about it. do you understand the predicament?

seeker:Yeah meet too it's just finding a way where I can maybe stay where I am whilst exploring other opportunities to see what I'd like to do. It's a tough one.

supporter:True! it would also be great for your self esteem to realise just how much more there is out there that you could be doing.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hi, how are you?
supporter:Hi there! I'm great, what about you? How can I help today?
seeker:My girlfriend dumped me for someone else! I've been really shook up.
supporter:I'm so sorry to hear that :( Do you have any idea why?
seeker:I think she just lost interest in me? 
It happened a couple of months ago. I wish I could get over it. I can't get her off my mind. She's dating this total loser.
supporter:That's tough... so you're saying that you grew apart a little? Or do you think it was more one-sided?
seeker:It probably was more me than her. 
Maybe I should have done more to show her that I cared for her. Am I not romantic enough? Some guys just aren't that way.
supporter:I completely understand, and I don't think you should beat yourself up over it!
seeker:That's a fair point. I shouldn't be too hard on myself.  I didn't really grow up in a romantic family. I don't know how to do that stuff, but maybe I could learn.
supporter:Exactly, and remember everyone is different, perhaps you just weren't her right one, and that can go both ways.
supporter:Do you want to improve for her? or for yourself do you think?
seeker:That's true. I really got hung up on her. I thought she was perfect and that we were perfect together. She didn't see it that way. I can't really change who I am, and she couldn't change who she is.
seeker:I don't know if I can change myself for her. Maybe there is something basic that she wants that I just don't have? I should probably change for future relationships.
supporter:That's a great line of thought, its good that you're able to identify that yourself
seeker:What do you think I could do to improve myself?
supporter:I suggest that you stay exactly the way that you are. I feel like you'd be happier that way and also more likely to find someone who shares the same values as you
supporter:If you change who you are, it sort of means that your ex still has a hold on you, you know?
seeker:Will the same problems show up in the next relationship though? It could be a long search before I find someone that matches with me?
seeker:That's true. But I feel like I should take away something from this experience.
supporter:I guess that depends on you, would you rather compromise for a relationship or find one who'll really last and not have to change?
seeker:I think all relationships require compromise and change. No two people are perfectly compatible.
seeker:I worry that I have blind spots that I should fix. My ex-GF didn't really specify what the problem was.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hello I would like to talk to you regarding my daily stresses
supporter:sure, please go ahead and share your story
seeker:pretty much being social isolated due to the pandemic, trying to finish up my studies at the same time, and what's going on in the world with regards to the pandemic. My physical and mental health aren't great, and I am not eating as well as I should or sleeping as well as I should.
seeker:I guess we all go through that in different ways with the pandemic now
supporter:it sounds like you are having depression, have you shared your problems with anyone?
seeker:yes sure, I chat with my friend everyday on the phone and that helps to talk about each other's day and my thoughts and feelings, observations with the world etc.
supporter:that's great! Friends can be big help
seeker:I am just not able to help my tendencies to sleep really late and wake up late. My sleep pattern is really abnormal and I am disappointed in myself. It's not much about the pandemic as just gotten a really bad habit and trying to stay up late and watch movies or catch up with my work. Then it's a vicious circle in which the next day I wake up late, and my day starts late, and so to get as much done, I repeat the same damaging cycle.
supporter:If you have time, spend at least 1-2h everyday outdoor. You can talk a walk in the park or just simply go to the stores
seeker:So I am having real trouble breaking this pattern. And because I work once or twice a week and not during the day, I don't even have the
 motivation or need to wake up early.
seeker:I go out only for personal errands and that's once every week or two weeks. I still am not prepared to go out even for walks. But that's just my stubborn thinking.
supporter:In order to have better sleep pattern, maybe you should exercise, at first your body will be tired which helps you sleep better and earlier
supporter:spending too much time indoor is very damaging to your mentality. Even the most normal person will go crazy at that rate.
seeker:My thinking is that I had stuck to this for so long it's not my style to compromise and I tend to be stubborn. And that if I had done that, I would have done that early on this year. But other people are doing it but it's also coupled with the pandemic in which I just don't think I or anyone should risk that, since I am basically sacrificing myself, while others in my apartment building are walking freely in and out. So that's my thinking.
seeker:Yes I understand. I do know it's bad to get stuck indoors. Believe me, before all this, I was going out many times a week to the movies and to the gym.
supporter:I feel you, when everything starts closing down again. I also feel angry because I've been doing everything right and now am punished because of other selfish people
seeker:Now I just do a lot of time nothing but on the computer or in my studies. A lot of the time aimless, not even studying that well or using my time well. And I don't have the same motivation to work out that much at home, which I used to do a lot.
seeker:exactly. I understand your feelings too on that.
seeker:A lot of selfish people inviting others indoors or going out, even a few months ago when the cases were just dropping and they didn't take enough time to wait but immediately lift their own restriction and go out.

seeker:Hi
supporter:Hello! How are you doing today?

seeker:I've been feeling down and anxious about getting older lately because I've lost may parents and I'm worried about losing my aunts.
supporter:I understand, you feel like your losing everyone close to you and wondering about your own mortality now as well?
seeker:Exactly, I worry about losing my aunts because they are in their 70s and 80s. I worry about my own mortality as well.
supporter:Have you told your aunts how much you love them? It may comfort you to know that you've shared exactly how you feel with them while they are here.
seeker:I tell them every time I talk to them and try to spend as much time with them as I can.
supporter:I try to let everyone know I love them too just because we never know when we aren't going to be here anymore. I definitely understand where you are coming from.
supporter:Have you tried looking at any YouTube videos about life and mortality?
seeker:I agree! We never know
seeker:I haven't but I will check some out. I love You Tube but never thought to look there.
supporter:I personally have found some comfort in hearing other people struggle with their own mortality or their beliefs in an after life or different things. Maybe that could be something you could try looking into.
seeker:I will definitely try that. It makes me feel better to know that you have found some comfort in hearing other people's struggles with their mortality or beliefs.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello how are you?
seeker:I'm, okay, thanks, and you?  I'm feeling a bit down because I'm alone for the holidays.
supporter:Well that's no good, does your family live far away?
seeker:Yes, my family is scattered all over the country, like Seattle, Georgia, PA.  I'm sure I'm not the only one with no plans this weekend, though.
supporter:True but I can understand that, it is hard being alone at the holidays.
supporter:Did you have plans this weekend?
seeker:No.  My nearby friends all went away for the holidays.  I could probably just occupy my time with things I need or want to do in order to distract myself.
supporter:What kind of hobbies do you have?
seeker:I'm teaching myself the piano.  I'm also teaching myself  how to work a stenography machine for possible future employment as a stenographer.  I also like to read novels.
supporter:I have never understood how those work..I find it amazing someone can type out whole words or sentences with one word
seeker:Yeah, it's pretty cool.  For example, if I hit DRAT in one stroke, then "Did there come a time" will appear in English on my machine's  LCD screen.
supporter:Wow that is crazy, I don't understand how that works, is it preprogrammed or does it go by how the word sounds?
seeker:Each stenographer has their own "Personal Dictionary" which is a list of words in English along with how you in particular write out those words or phrases in steno.  This dictionary is present within the actual steno machine after you transfer it from your laptop to the machine via cable or wifi.  Thus your machine then knows how you write out words in particular and how to translate those words from steno to English - each stenographer writes a little differently.
supporter:OK that makes sense, so you basically program it as the user. I take it your stenography machine becomes pretty close to you lol
supporter:Is this your first holiday alone?
seeker:Yes, exactly!  And it's very important to back up your personal dictionary to the cloud or a seperate drive so that you don't lose it in a hard-drive crash.  A lot of work goes into creating that dictionary!  No, it's happened before, being along for the holidays; but you've helped to cheer me up, so thanks!

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:I hate how some people voted
supporter:Why do you feel that way?
seeker:because if biden really does win he's gonna fuck with everyones gun rights
supporter:You seem really concerned about gun rights. Does that sound possible?
seeker:i am an army veteran
seeker:i defended the county and risked my life. i want to defend my children and my home how that i am back in country
supporter:Thank you for your service. I can understand how that might be a difficult situation for you, especially with your experiences. How are you handling this situation?
seeker:thank you. i'm just really worried. my neighbor is a single woman. last month her boyfriend beat her up and she called the police. it took 35 minutes to respond
seeker:i have an 8 year old daughter and five year old twin boys. i want to protect my children from harm
supporter:You are welcome. That is really kind of you to want to protect your children from harm. It seems like you feel the best way to do this is through owning guns? Have you thought of any alternatives, since the votes have been cast?
seeker:what alternative? the police are so backed up everywhere they can't respond fast enough. they should be our first line of defense here in the us against bad guys but that doesnt happen or they ccant always be trusted to respond quickly and efficiently so i feel we have to take it upon ourselves. if someone were to break in and has a gun.... i mean.. criminals dont get guns the legal way anyway you know. what should i do...throw a knife at them? lol
supporter:That is a good point you bring up about the quickness and efficiency of protection that guns can provide.
supporter:How you thought of any other alternatives that could help your family, regarding the process of obtaining guns during a Biden presidency?
seeker:not a clue. do you have any suggestions?
supporter:Definitely! My first step would be understanding the gun policy that Biden would have and confirming the new process. Does that sound like something that could be a good starting point?
seeker:true..i may be worrying over nothing
supporter:I think you are just being careful and protective of your family. That is very honorable of a veteran like yourself.
seeker:thank you
seeker:i guess going to war makes you worry about things a lot of people dont normally have to huh
supporter:Yes, that sounds like the case. Are there any practices that have helped you when you're worried?
seeker:well...the va has me do jornaling, deep breathing and mediation. kinda embarasing to admit...
supporter:Don't be embarrassed! To be honest, I have had experiences with some of those, including deep breathing. I also find it helpful.
seeker:thanks for sharing. that makes me feel better. :)
supporter:Of course! I am glad to share and help :)
seeker:I'm glad we talked. I. hope you have a great day and a great. holiday season!

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hi, how are you? What would you like to discuss today?
seeker:Hello my name is Marie
seeker:I have a lot of depression
seeker:I feel like I'm always hurting
supporter:Hi, Marie. You are dealing with depression. I'm sorry to hear that.
seeker:I have low energy most of the time except for when I'm working
supporter:What is it about work that gets you going?
seeker:My job is fast paced I work for a call center working from home
supporter:You spend a lot of your day talking and interacting with people. Do you enjoy the work?
seeker:I'm always taking one call after the other and barely got time to think about my problems I'm dealing with
seeker:I enjoy my job
supporter:The work distracts you from your problems but it does not give you time to address them.
seeker:I feel like I get to help alot of people
seeker:it distracts me from my problems exactly
supporter:I'm sure you do! Phone support requires a lot of patient explanation. That is challenging for many people.
seeker:I'm actually one of the best at my job
seeker:I wish I was that good with myself personally
supporter:I'm glad you have found success and fulfillment at your work.
seeker:Thank you
supporter:If your job is good for you, what do you think makes you feel depressed then?
seeker:I don't know what I'm going to myself when I'm not working
seeker:I feel hopeless about many things
supporter:Exercise? Reading? School? Friends?
supporter:Hopelessness might be something that you have learned because you have expectations.
supporter:Do you feel that there has to be some sort of result? Progress? Improvement?
seeker:trying to lose weight, trying to void getting diabetes, having better conversation with boyfriend , convince him to spend more time with me instead of work buddies after work hours, want to finish college, being able to buy a house, improving my credit, convincing my dad and brother to get mental help
supporter:If you didn't do any of those things ever, how would you feel about yourself?
seeker:having a more active lifestyle , 
making new friends
seeker:those are things I need to accomplish
supporter:Now imagine you achieve all of those things, and you do so in spectacular fashion. Would you be happy? Or would you find another reason to feel hopeless?
seeker:I believe those are the things that have been bothering me for a long time
seeker:not being able to accomplish those things makes me feel hopeless
seeker:frustrated
seeker:feel like I'm meaningless to thers
supporter:It's important to remember that you choose what goals to pursue. You decide the criteria for success and failure. You are the final arbiter of your life.
seeker:those are all goals in my life that I need to reach
seeker:I just don't know how most of the time
supporter:I understand. We all have goals. Goals can be helpful. But ask yourself why you chose those particular goals.
seeker:I feel like I can't get guidance anywhere
seeker:those are goals that when I accomplish them it will make me feel better
supporter:It sounds like you need someone to tell you what to do, or to give you permission to do what you want to do.
seeker:if I accomplish them it will feel like there was improvement
seeker:probably I've been used to my dad telling me what to do for a long time
seeker:I lack self motivation
supporter:If you need permission, I hereby grant you permission to pursue what is meaningful to you.
supporter:You gave me a list of things that you want to achieve. Pick one.
seeker:I want to do
 all those
seeker:I'm not sure what should I do first
supporter:I understand. Which one is more important. Which is the one you can do right away? Also: which one do you really *not* want to do?
seeker:I feel like all those goals will take some time
seeker:can't be accomplish right away
supporter:Of course. Anything worthwhile takes time.
seeker:I need to stay on top of those goals but I feel like I get side tracked
supporter:You feel compelled to pursue these goals. Why? If you don't, what is the worst that could happen? What if you only pursued one goal?
seeker:pursuing only one of these will not be enough to make me happy I will keep thinking about the goals I need to accomplish
supporter:You need to readjust your expectations, which are causing you to feel unhappy.
seeker:is there a technique that you can suggest I follow to feel self motivated and keep my goals organized and in check
seeker:I will feel successful after completing most of these goals
supporter:Pick a small action, like making your bed. Establish a habit of doing it daily. It will be easy to build on that success, but you might first establish a habit.
seeker:yeah sometimes I don't make the bed I wait to see if my boyfriends makes it sometimes
seeker:sometimes I do make the bed
seeker:it's not that bad doing that
supporter:Make the bed every day. Then pick another small goal.
seeker:I actually feel good about my self after making the bed
seeker:procrastination seems to get the best of me
seeker:I wish I made the bed more often
supporter:That is evidence that you should continue that behavior.
seeker:that sounds weird
seeker:not what you said I referring to what I said I think it was weird
seeker:right?
seeker:maybe you're right I need to make it a habit
supporter:What do you think sounds weird?
seeker:I need to make the bed more often since it makes me feel good after making it
supporter:That is not weird at all.
seeker:oh okay thanks
supporter:When we accomplish something, our brain rewards us with chemicals.
seeker:wow
seeker:that's good to know
supporter:It sounds like your brain just gave you a squirt of chemicals.
seeker:that explains that feeling after making the bed
seeker:lol
supporter:You have some big goals. Break them down into smaller ones.
seeker:yes I think those are mostly big goals that's why I don't know where to start
supporter:Weight loss is quantitative. Pick a number.
seeker:pick a number?

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello
seeker:Hi
supporter:How is everything
seeker:Not the best.  I have been quarantined for 5 weeks with COVID-19 (tested positive), so I am getting cabin fever.
supporter:Ready for the holidays
supporter:So you tested positive, must be hard
seeker:I am starting to get an aversion to holidays.  When I was in college, my father was dying, and Thanksgiving was the last meal he ate at the family table...
Christmas was the last time he ate solid food,
and he died on the day after Epiphany
seeker:So I have come to associate Thanksgiving through January as a time of loss.
supporter:The holidays can bring back memories, but you have other family around right
seeker:This month has driven it home more, because I have had six people die this month.  It's starting to bring on flashbacks.
seeker:No, my family all moved from the area.  The nearest is now half a country away and hasn't spoken to me in over ten years.
supporter:The virus is hard. along with the season
seeker:It's been... interesting.
supporter:You must have friends around, right. have you contacted any
supporter:How long ago did your dad pass away
seeker:Ahhh... I hate to be that guy, but I really don't have that many friends.  I have a couple people at my church who have checked in, but I wouldn't go so far as to call them friends (we don't hang out, I don't get invited over...)
seeker:I was in college.  He died slowly and painfully.  It was really unpleasant.
seeker:And he was a brilliant man.  I could only wish to be half of what he was.
supporter:That can cause loneliness as well. What about seeing if your family will chat and let them know you ae ok
seeker:I don't even have contact information for them anymore.  The last known phone numbers have been disconnected and the last time I sent mail, it was returned for wrong address, no forwarding information known.
seeker:I think they forgot about me.
supporter:Comparing yourself to others can be a positive and give you reason to strive more
seeker:The only one I still have contact with is my mother.
supporter:Have you checked to see if she is ok
seeker:I avoid comparing myself to others.  I usually come out on the bad side of it.
seeker:I talk to her regularly.  She is okay, but I fear she is reaching the age where I know I won't have her much longer.
supporter:But use your dad as inspiration
seeker:I'm just thankful I have had her this long
seeker:That I do.  While I will never have the skills my father had technically, I am thankful that I did get his ability to be analytical and his compassion for others.
supporter:See that is a positive thing. You both need each other
supporter:That is great to hear. He is a role model  for you
seeker:Absolutely.  I still remember him teaching me things that I use to this day.  I still smile when I think of one time when he first became ill and couldn't get out of bed...
seeker:there was a project he wanted to do and it bothered him that it had not gotten done.  Well, I was able to do it, because he had taught me enough to know what to do.
supporter:That is a positive in itself. Keep his legacy going through you
seeker:The look of pride in his face was priceless.
supporter:And you have that memory to live by
seeker:The one thing I carry on because of him is my love for my church.  He was on the church vestry (governing board).  I am on my church worship team.
supporter:His smile is in your heart and you can still feel him
seeker:I actually made church history, because I sing with the praise team (some churches call that a choir), but I sing many of the songs in American Sign Language.
seeker:I am the first signing member of the church.
supporter:See that there in itself is a reason to smile
seeker:2021 will be the 50 year anniversary of our congregation.
seeker:I joined just over ten years ago.
seeker:My church is my anchor.
supporter:You are a positive for your church. Not many can sign language
seeker:My pastor is wonderful.  He is like the little brother I didn't have but always wanted.
supporter:That is awesome. See you have a purpose
supporter:I imagine he is missing his big sister
seeker:My favorite story about signing in the church is how it began...  I had asked to do it and had been shot down cold six times.  Well, I laugh now, but at the time I was angry.
seeker:If you mean me, I'm male.
seeker:But the last time I was told I could not sign for the church, I told the elder who said no that God was going to give him a sign.
supporter:But your determination kept your dream alive.sorry big brother
supporter:You are a very determined person. Don't let the fire die inside your heart
seeker:Well, God delivered on the promise quickly.  That same who  morning we had a family visit who were on a road trip.  They just were passing through but wanted to go to church while travelling.
supporter:The Lord is using you to each others/
seeker:They had a little girl about 6 or 7 years old who was Deaf.  She saw me sitting in the back of the sanctuary signing the lyrics to the songs, and praying in Sign.  Her face lit up and she started signing too.
seeker:At the end of the service, she found me and gave me a big hug around my legs and then looked up and said "I always wanted to go to a church where someone knew MY language!"

supporter:hi! how's your day going?

supporter:that's a hard way to find out. are you still in the same house?
seeker:Yes because for financial reasons we have to be. Our relationship is really strained though and we are sleeping in separate bedrooms.
supporter:i can't imagine what you are going through, but separate spaces sounds like a very good idea to me.
seeker:It is made worse by the fact that we are in lockdown and so can't really see other people at the moment. Do you think I should try and break away for good?
supporter:before you take any action, i'd ask myself what are your options?
supporter:you know that his actions have very little to do with you and more to do with him, right?
seeker:Well, I could move out but I can't afford to rent a flat on my own. I'd have to move in with my parents, realistically.
seeker:I keep telling myself that but I feel really betrayed. I keep wondering what she is like and whether she is prettier and more successful than me.
supporter:are your parents supportive of that idea?
seeker:I have not really talked to them about it. I feel a bit ashamed having to admit to them that my relationship has not worked out.
supporter:it's not about her or you. it's about him.
seeker:But I can't help thinking that perhaps I did something wrong that made him stray?
supporter:they will understand. opening up to them will be the hardest part. it's a shame cocktail, but it's not one you made
seeker:Do you think that there is any point at all in trying to mend things at this stage? He has promised he will not see her again but I don't think I could ever trust him.
supporter:it's in our nature as women to ask "what did I do?" but it is never about us or anything we did.
seeker:Thank you, I am really glad that you understand. I don't feel that I will ever be able to trust any man again!
supporter:trust and vunerability is huge in a relationship. i'd look for professional help if you wan tot try and work on it

supporter:do you have a friend who has been through a similar situation? sometime that helps.

also, sharing your burden with someone does NOT add to their burden

seeker:work*

seeker:Really well, I enjoy being there.  And it pays well, so can't go wrong with those two positives.
supporter:Absolutely, I think finding a job that you are passionate about is a goal for a majority of people.
seeker:Yep, it works fine for me.  Can't complain very much about it.
supporter:That's awesome, is there any aspect about your job that you don't like or enjoy as much?
seeker:To be honest, not really.  I pretty much self-manage and do not have to deal with people, which is a good thing for me.  Every now and then I'll have to work with a new person who isn't as competent and that can be frustrating.
supporter:I can understand it, it sounds like you are in a position where you oversee others are in a teaching capacity. I too am in a similar position, and when people aren't as responsive to my ideas, it can definitely irritate me.
seeker:Yeah.  It's more of a competency problem with me I think.  I'm fine if people aren't responsive to my personal ideas, but as far as a work situation - or any situation where there are pre-agreed situations that must be dealt in certain ways - that is frustrating.  I think I expect too much  from people - but really my expectations aren't that high, I don't think - if I really think about it.
supporter:That makes sense, but it might be helpful to think about the other person's situation. Perhaps he/she hasn't had the same amount of training? Perhaps, they just need a little more guidance than other people who are more able to complete the tasks.
seeker:That is true, and a good point.  My main issue - it's not just related to work - I'm not a "liker" of people in general, but I am nice to everyone. I have a hard time relating to most people.
supporter:What aspects do you especially have a hard time relating with?
seeker:Well, it seems someone has to have to have gone through some hard times as well, for me to relate to them.  And to have learned from those hard times.  So that cuts out a good bit of people who have had good lives - and then half the people who have gone through some stuff haven't learned from it and made themselves better.  So it
s
seeker:So I have to try to weed everyone out, but that's exhausting.
supporter:That does sound exhausting, though some people might be reluctant to share their personal experiences, and it might be helpful to start smaller when getting to know someone and working up to more serious conversations.
seeker:Thats good advice.  Often Im fine with the way thjngs are going, but every once in a while it bothers me.
supporter:I think it's great that it doesn't happen often and that you are able to recognize the few situations where it does begin to bother you.
seeker:Yeah I try to stay cognizant of these things.  Ive had some psych training so it helps out.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hi there
supporter:Hello.  How's it going?
seeker:I've not been doing great to be honest. I'm finding it hard to stay positive with all these constant lockdowns and 
restrictions
supporter:I can agree.  There are so many places going back to where we were several months ago.  Which state do you live in?
seeker:I'm actually from the UK. I live in the North of the country near Manchester and things are bad here right now.
supporter:I agree it's bad!  Where I live in the US our numbers are going back up and the kids are being home schooled again.  I just keep thinking this is temporary!
seeker:Yes I suppose it does help to think it possible not for the long term but my friends seem to be dealing with it better than I am and I'm not quite sure why it's put me in such a sad emotional state. I should just get on with it but have very low motivation
supporter:I have to say it's hard to find motivation and I was in that spot at the beginning.  With news of vaccines being introduced here shortly, that's what's keeping me afloat.  Are you able to hang out with friends?
seeker:no not really because I'm not supposed to mix with people outside of my household. I could potentially try and meet them virtually online or on a video call is this something you've had much experience with?
supporter:Oh very much so!  Zoom and Facetime are my best friends right now.  lol I think that's one of the reasons why I snapped out of my depression is because I started doing that more since we couldn't go out and do anything.
seeker:Ok that's interesting so you have also suffered with depression in the past? exactly how did you get out of it yourself?
supporter:I downloaded Zoom around the end of May.  The first two months were the worst. I had never heard of Zoom until a friend said we should have a virtual party so he organized it and there were 11 on the call.  It was so much fun despite the fact.
supporter:Maybe organizing a "zoom party" would start to lift your spirits.
seeker:that's a really good suggestion. I could also catch up with friends that haven't seen for a while. I think this would definitely work to boost my mood. The only problem is being depressed isn't something that I'm familiar with. what if it goes a little bit deeper than this?
supporter:Depression sucks I have to say!  Just don't let it win.  Since you say it's something you have never dealt with, you can fight it by staying upbeat and do something fun.
seeker:Sure, or something conversations like this help perhaps a support group would be a good idea also?
supporter:Start off by not being hard on yourself for feeling the way you do.  Music, tv and books does it for me - and zoom

seeker:Yo
supporter:Hi, how are you doing?
seeker:I am decent. I am here because my friend talks way too much on the phone, and it frustrates me.
seeker:They never want to hang up, and the talk can literally go on for hours.
supporter:It sounds like it would be quite frustrating for your friend to talk way too much on the phone.
seeker:No, he loves it! I'm the one who hates it.
supporter:My goodness! How do they respond when you ask to end the conversation?
seeker:I tell him, but he just doesn't get it. Or, he says he understands, but then just goes back to talking!
seeker:Or, he may finally end the talk, but the next time we talk, he will just do it all over again!
supporter:I wonder what it would be like for him if you hung up the phone even after he said he still wanted to talk.
supporter:Wow--that does sound annoying that he will repeat the same pattern the next time.
seeker:He will literally talk up to 10 minutes without letting you have a word in. As far as that advice, I have hung up, but he gets extremely offended easily.
supporter:That sounds really difficult if he gets offended so easily. I find it hard to talk to some of those kinds of friends.
seeker:I'm at my wits end. I tell him all the time. "You talk too much. You gotta stop talking at me. You gotta give the other person a turn. You gotta respect other's time."
supporter:What do you get out of the friendship with this other person?
seeker:Well, I've been friends with him for a long time. He's funny and can have interesting perspectives on things. Also, we have done a lot together in the past.
supporter:That sounds like a lot that the two of you have been through. Were there other times that your friends was more equally responsive or attuned to you in conversations?
seeker:Oh, yes, I have other friends in conversations who can take turns and understand the concept of time just fine.
seeker:I just don't know what to do about this guy in particular. I still want to be his friend, but he just doesn't change.
supporter:I wonder if there is anything nice you could do for yourself when you are talking to him that would make it easier to talk to him.
seeker:Do you think I should just have a timer that goes off at 1 minute and let it beep in his face if he goes on for too long to train him like a monkey?
supporter:I can see that you are feeling upset and angry when he talks so much and that is totally understandable.
seeker:I just need a method. Talking to him is just not working.
seeker:He is hard to condition.
supporter:Would it hurt his feelings to use a timer like that? It may for some other people.
seeker:Yea, but I might be able to slip some humour in there to take the edge off because it is so silly.
supporter:Humor is really helpful for a lot of people.
seeker:Any other ideas?
supporter:Sometimes, people draw or do something else distracting with their hands when talking to someone who dominates the conversation.
seeker:So your option is to start just doing something else when he is talking? He might get the message in a subtle way?
supporter:Sometimes that is a less offensive way to retrain someone who is being obnoxious or dominant and yet who is easily offended. And, it can help preserve your sense of being grounded.

And now so many months have gone by, and all that's on my mind and plate now are my studies, because it's like I do things slower and leave it till the last minute, even though I know I can pass, but just not as good a mark as I would have liked and not my usual work and study ethics from before.

seeker:Yo

seeker:No, he loves it! I'm the one who hates it.
supporter:My goodness! How do they respond when you ask to end the conversation?
seeker:I tell him, but he just doesn't get it. Or, he says he understands, but then just goes back to talking!
seeker:Or, he may finally end the talk, but the next time we talk, he will just do it all over again!
supporter:I wonder what it would be like for him if you hung up the phone even after he said he still wanted to talk.
supporter:Wow--that does sound annoying that he will repeat the same pattern the next time.
seeker:He will literally talk up to 10 minutes without letting you have a word in. As far as that advice, I have hung up, but he gets extremely offended easily.
supporter:That sounds really difficult if he gets offended so easily. I find it hard to talk to some of those kinds of friends.
seeker:I'm at my wits end. I tell him all the time. "You talk too much. You gotta stop talking at me. You gotta give the other person a turn. You gotta respect other's time."
supporter:What do you get out of the friendship with this other person?
seeker:Well, I've been friends with him for a long time. He's funny and can have interesting perspectives on things. Also, we have done a lot together in the past.
supporter:That sounds like a lot that the two of you have been through. Were there other times that your friends was more equally responsive or attuned to you in conversations?
seeker:Oh, yes, I have other friends in conversations who can take turns and understand the concept of time just fine.
seeker:I just don't know what to do about this guy in particular. I still want to be his friend, but he just doesn't change.
supporter:I wonder if there is anything nice you could do for yourself when you are talking to him that would make it easier to talk to him.
seeker:Do you think I should just have a timer that goes off at 1 minute and let it beep in his face if he goes on for too long to train him like a monkey?
supporter:I can see that you are feeling upset and angry when he talks so much and that is totally understandable.
seeker:I just need a method. Talking to him is just not working.
seeker:He is hard to condition.

seeker:Yea, but I might be able to slip some humour in there to take the edge off because it is so silly.
supporter:Humor is really helpful for a lot of people.
seeker:Any other ideas?
supporter:Sometimes, people draw or do something else distracting with their hands when talking to someone who dominates the conversation.
seeker:So your option is to start just doing something else when he is talking? He might get the message in a subtle way?
supporter:Sometimes that is a less offensive way to retrain someone who is being obnoxious or dominant and yet who is easily offended. And, it can help preserve your sense of being grounded.
supporter:The strategy works well for me with some of my family members who seem like they will never change. But, with distraction, I enjoy them all the more.
seeker:This is true, and it isn't bade advice. Haha! That is funny. Yes, maybe I should find something to carry around with me that I can enjoy.
seeker:I don't really like to draw...
supporter:Is there anything else that you like to do that would be distracting while also letting you somewhat participate in the conversation?
seeker:Yes, perhaps I should just use the internet when he starts talking too much.
seeker:I have a phone.
supporter:That sounds really helpful. Sometimes people also play phone games or with a fidget spinner. I like your idea of looking on the internet.

seeker:I don't want to take up any more of your time. It has been a good conversation.

Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello! How are you doing today?
seeker:I've been better to be honest. I think I need to break up with my girlfriend but she moved in last year and I don;'
 know how to approach it. I think I'm going to be in for a bad emotional time
supporter:That seems like a tough situation! What feelings made you decide you need to breakup with her?
seeker:It's a bit of a mix. I don't find her attractive that much any more and I think that's important. Also since moving in she is difficult to live with. I can't see myself with her long term.
supporter:I completely understand that. I recently broke up with my boyfriend earlier this year, because I didn't feel like I loved him as much as I used to. Things like that are important!
supporter:How long have you guys been together?
seeker:It's good that you have had a similar experience and understand what I'm going through. We dated for a while. The thing is she is Italian and has moved countries to live with me. I feel so bad that this has happened.
supporter:Oh I see. That's a huge step to make in a relationship. So you are hesitant to break up with her because she moved just to be with you?
supporter:Have you communicated with her about your concerns? Such as being difficult to live with?
seeker:Yes that's right, I helped her get a job and thought I'd just see how it goes. Her family loves me and thinks I'm great which makes this even more difficult. We have talked about things yes but she sees it as a bit of a joke I think.
supporter:I think it's great that we got matched up, because I went through also the exact same situation. My boyfriend and I were long distance, and he moved across the country to be closer to me. So when I felt like we needed to break up, I was experiencing similar guilt that you are experiencing.
seeker:It's great that you understand this. I think being the man puts more pressure on me to look after her and make sure she
seeker:she's safe etc
supporter:I want to reassure you, that doing what's best for you is what is most important! Your partner will understand this if they truly care for you. Things will be tough for a while, but you both will be able to grow from this experience. And just because you don't want to be in a relationship anymore, doesn't mean that you don't care about her!
supporter:Staying friends after the fact might take the pressure off of you a little bit. You can still help her out and be there for each other, but as friends instead of partner's.
seeker:To be honest, it's amazing that you have suggested this. It's really hard to balance my needs and feelings without breaking her heart. It's hard for the person that's dumped but actually I think it is equally hard for the dumper!
supporter:Yes exactly! It's so difficult for the dumper as well, because of course you still have strong feelings for this person. They just aren't romantic anymore.
supporter:And that is okay. You don't need to feel guilty for things that you can't control. You can still be there for her without pretending to be in love
seeker:That's exactly it. So do you think I should just talk to her and tell her how I feel? The thing is it's not like she can move out immediately. It's going to be a long drawn out experience.
supporter:I think talking to her and being transparent about your feelings is definitely the right move. In doing this, reassure her you still want to be friends and you aren't just "kicking her to the curb." Things will obviously be awkward for the first little bit, because continuing to live together will bring it's own difficulties. But the beautiful thing about that is, you guys are already used to it. :) So it's only hard if you make it hard
seeker:Yes, I think I need to emphasize the friends element of it and potentially support her to move on. I suppose I'm fearful that it will never end but I'll need to face into that and stay strong, and obviously avoid being intimate as this would really hurt her if I continued to sleep with her. I need to be careful about that I think!

supporter:Hello, how are you doing today?

supporter:Do you feel like you can't take any actions in the situation?
seeker:Long story short - at work, a new boss pulled all the leadership OUT of the jobs they were hired for (some more than 12 years ago - so they have lots of experience) and shuffled them all around to new jobs - all that is except the 5 oldest employees - they got moved into "non-positions". No longer supervising anyone, only doing grunt work, etc. It ticks me off and there's nothing I can do about it.
seeker:I'm working on a *possible* action - RETIREMENT from this job. Only problem is - bad time to be doing that; pressure to keep my income up until my daughter graduates college, etc.
supporter:That sounds frustrating, especially if you're one of the employees affected and when the new boss doesn't seem to know what he/she is doing with the reorganization.
supporter:That's positive, though, that you at least have a strategy in mind with retirement, even if this may not be the best time right now.
seeker:She has a "plan", I guess, but it isn't being articulated that well, and these actions are demonstrating poor "people management" and seem to be both confusing lots of folks, and professionally insulting many others. Oh, and by the way, things are running WORSE than they were before, but it's being blamed on COVID
seeker:Problem with the "retirement strategy" is that it means going out on a limb with no job with the holidays coming up, and with COVID with no end in sight. SO, just "muddling through" the days these days, hoping better times are ahead.

supporter:Wow! From what you've said, it sounds like your coworkers feel much as you do about the changes.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hi, how are you? What would you like to discuss today?
seeker:Hello my name is Marie
seeker:I have a lot of depression
seeker:I feel like I'm always hurting
supporter:Hi, Marie. You are dealing with depression. I'm sorry to hear that.
seeker:I have low energy most of the time except for when I'm working
supporter:What is it about work that gets you going?
seeker:My job is fast paced I work for a call center working from home
supporter:You spend a lot of your day talking and interacting with people. Do you enjoy the work?
seeker:I'm always taking one call after the other and barely got time to think about my problems I'm dealing with
seeker:I enjoy my job
supporter:The work distracts you from your problems but it does not give you time to address them.
seeker:I feel like I get to help alot of people
seeker:it distracts me from my problems exactly
supporter:I'm sure you do! Phone support requires a lot of patient explanation. That is challenging for many people.
seeker:I'm actually one of the best at my job
seeker:I wish I was that good with myself personally
supporter:I'm glad you have found success and fulfillment at your work.
seeker:Thank you
supporter:If your job is good for you, what do you think makes you feel depressed then?
seeker:I don't know what I'm going to myself when I'm not working
seeker:I feel hopeless about many things
supporter:Exercise? Reading? School? Friends?
supporter:Hopelessness might be something that you have learned because you have expectations.
supporter:Do you feel that there has to be some sort of result? Progress? Improvement?
seeker:trying to lose weight, trying to void getting diabetes, having better conversation with boyfriend , convince him to spend more time with me instead of work buddies after work hours, want to finish college, being able to buy a house, improving my credit, convincing my dad and brother to get mental help
supporter:If you didn't do any of those things ever, how would you feel about yourself?
seeker:having a more active lifestyle , 
making new friends
seeker:those are things I need to accomplish
supporter:Now imagine you achieve all of those things, and you do so in spectacular fashion. Would you be happy? Or would you find another reason to feel hopeless?
seeker:I believe those are the things that have been bothering me for a long time
seeker:not being able to accomplish those things makes me feel hopeless
seeker:frustrated
seeker:feel like I'm meaningless to thers
supporter:It's important to remember that you choose what goals to pursue. You decide the criteria for success and failure. You are the final arbiter of your life.
seeker:those are all goals in my life that I need to reach
seeker:I just don't know how most of the time
supporter:I understand. We all have goals. Goals can be helpful. But ask yourself why you chose those particular goals.
seeker:I feel like I can't get guidance anywhere
seeker:those are goals that when I accomplish them it will make me feel better
supporter:It sounds like you need someone to tell you what to do, or to give you permission to do what you want to do.
seeker:if I accomplish them it will feel like there was improvement
seeker:probably I've been used to my dad telling me what to do for a long time
seeker:I lack self motivation
supporter:If you need permission, I hereby grant you permission to pursue what is meaningful to you.
supporter:You gave me a list of things that you want to achieve. Pick one.
seeker:I want to do
 all those
seeker:I'm not sure what should I do first
supporter:I understand. Which one is more important. Which is the one you can do right away? Also: which one do you really *not* want to do?
seeker:I feel like all those goals will take some time
seeker:can't be accomplish right away
supporter:Of course. Anything worthwhile takes time.
seeker:I need to stay on top of those goals but I feel like I get side tracked
supporter:You feel compelled to pursue these goals. Why? If you don't, what is the worst that could happen? What if you only pursued one goal?
seeker:pursuing only one of these will not be enough to make me happy I will keep thinking about the goals I need to accomplish
supporter:You need to readjust your expectations, which are causing you to feel unhappy.
seeker:is there a technique that you can suggest I follow to feel self motivated and keep my goals organized and in check
seeker:I will feel successful after completing most of these goals
supporter:Pick a small action, like making your bed. Establish a habit of doing it daily. It will be easy to build on that success, but you might first establish a habit.
seeker:yeah sometimes I don't make the bed I wait to see if my boyfriends makes it sometimes
seeker:sometimes I do make the bed
seeker:it's not that bad doing that
supporter:Make the bed every day. Then pick another small goal.
seeker:I actually feel good about my self after making the bed
seeker:procrastination seems to get the best of me
seeker:I wish I made the bed more often
supporter:That is evidence that you should continue that behavior.
seeker:that sounds weird
seeker:not what you said I referring to what I said I think it was weird
seeker:right?
seeker:maybe you're right I need to make it a habit
