supporter:Do you have an advisor who is holding you accountable?
seeker:Yes, but I've been really bad about keeping her in the loop. I feel bad when I fall behind, and then I'm fearful of getting back in touch with her.
supporter:Whenever I have a large project and lose motivation, I set my goals on paper, then break it down into smaller bites. For example, I will make sure I work one hour on certain days, or call a friend, I generate ideas to keep me on track.
supporter:Yes, I sometimes feel guilty and then don't want to face the music, but actually the best thing to do is recognize you are NOT the first person she knows that got behind. So she is surely experienced with people who need some encouragement. She is the BEST person to go to, actually.
seeker:That sounds like a good idea regarding putting it down on paper.
supporter:It has always helped me. For example, you can break it down into 4 weeks, then each week write your goals -- maybe put call Advisor or go stop by every week, but I would put that first for the first week.
supporter:Then as you check off items, you will see you are moving, even if at a snail's pace, you are moving, and that always encourages me. Sometimes I do not realize how much I AM doing, until I see it on paper. Paper doesn't lie, but my emotions sometimes cloud my thinking.
seeker:My other problem is that I'm a perfectionist. I tend to over-analyze and get bogged down, especially when doing research.
supporter:Another idea is rewards, when you finish one goal, perhaps put a reward for yourself,  a yogurt with sprinkles or something like that
supporter:You sound like me! I had to learn that I need to strive for EXCELLENCE, not perfection. Perfection will drain us. Do the best I can, leave the rest to God.
supporter:That is why a time line is good. For example, you make a goal that you will work on your reference and citation page for one hour, after that, you are DONE, If you have time at the end, you can revisit it. The hour is my suggestion, you make your own. lol THAT way, you don't get caught going on and on for 6 hours to make it perfect. One hour is reasonable.
seeker:That definitely sounds reasonable. Putting micro deadlines in might be what I need to do to keep me focused.
supporter:I do this with EVERYTHING in life because I tend to go on and on too focused and lose track of everything. lol For example, I clean each room for 15 minutes a week. If it needs more, I do more, but I set the timer and you would be surprised how well that works, otherwise, I will spend all my time perfecting one room and the rest is a mess.
supporter:Also, your Advisor will know tips to help you too. She has advised a lot of people, her objectivity and experience can give get RIGHT to the heart of any problem, quickly too.
seeker:My advisor is a tough woman, I'm not going to beat around the bush. She tends to make everything miserable.
supporter:Tough advisors are TOUGH. lol But You sound intelligent and you obviously WANT to do this, it is a goal of yours, I'm sure you can take it!
seeker:I'll try to keep that in mind. It's something I do feel like I need to finish for my own sake.
supporter:It is only one more month of your life. If you buckle down, it will be over and done with before you know it. And I assure you, you will look back in pride at your accomplishments!
seeker:That sounds like a wonderful feeling. But so far away.
supporter:My Graduation Day was amazing.  This is what life is about, working NOW for rewards later. It's like a garden, you sow, you weed, you wait for rain and weed some more. You keep waiting and weeding, then later harvest come. It takes time to work a little each day, then time passes whether you lay on your bed or whether you are in the garden working. If you lay on your bed, you get nothing, if you work a little every day, in time, you reap rewards.
seeker:That's a very poetic way of putting it.

appen anytime.

prompt.content:

seeker:Hi there.
supporter:Hello. How are you feeling today?
seeker:I am feeling pretty down about my appearance.
supporter:I get that way too. Is there any particular cause or aspect you are focussed on?
seeker:It is mainly my weight i just can't seem to loose any and it is making me quite sad.
supporter:Gosh I am very sorry to hear that you are struggling to loose weight and it is making you sad. May I ask what you are doing to attempt to loose the weight? I hear cardio is very good for that.
seeker:Well i do use my bike. But i really struggle with motivation and i know i snack too much. But i have just been too busy to spend any real time facing the problem, you know?
supporter:I totally understand. I was the same way over worked and under motivated. I found that mixing in low impact weight work outs was really effective as well as each morning setting out healthy snacks that way i don't have to think about getting something it is already there.
seeker:Oh that is a good idea what do you suggest?
supporter:Honestly my top favorite are chocolate covered almonds and sugar snap peas. have you tried lowering your carb and increasing your protein intake?
seeker:No i hadn't thought about that don't you have to only drink protein if your work out.
supporter:Typically yes but having a low protein shake, ie one scoop not too, everyday is a great way to supplement your caloric intake with protein. You will find yourself less hungry and have more energy through the day.
seeker:That actually makes a lot of sense. What about motivation i really need help with that i find when i am less motivated i am deffinitely more depressed.
supporter:Lots of people also struggle with depressive episodes and low motivation. Don't worry you are not alone. It is important to try and think is it depression related low motivation or vice versa.
seeker:thats true how can you tell. it is really hard for me right now.
supporter:That's ok. Don't worry everything will be ok. Remember little steps forward are better and easier to achieve. even if it seems really bad right now just know it will always get better.
seeker:Thats true.

seeker:Yes, but online seems to be hit and miss as there are scams out there right now too.
supporter:Happily I have found it to be good and honest work in general so I'd not worry too much :)
seeker:Yes, I am as I have over 15 years of warehouse experience as well as forklift experience.
supporter:What sort of field would you like to move into after the pandemic?
seeker:I would like to getting back into the warehousing or forklift operator field.
supporter:So you feel that your life is just on hiatus at the moment and you want it to get back to the way it was as soon as possible?

seeker:Not really, although I do talk to my family about this matter.
supporter:I hope that I have been able to help you and it was nice to talk!

supporter:Hello, how are you today?

supporter:I feel a lot of people are in your situation especially with Covid going on.  Do you connect with friends on social media at all (like facebook)?
seeker:Yea, I do comment on their social media and follow up with their lives there. I used to visit my friends too and we'd have lunch or coffee at their house, but obviously I haven't been able to do that lately.  I will be able to once I get the vaccine.
supporter:I was able to get my first dose of this vaccine this past Sunday.  I was very surprised how good I felt this week like a weight being lifted off my shoulders. I not it might not help for you today but I think it will give you something to look forward as you move forward in the upcoming weeks.
supporter:*I know
seeker:That's so exciting for you!  I am hoping I will be able to get mine in the coming weeks.  I've definitely been looking forward to getting it.  I decided a week ago that I would get a puppy as a companion.  So I am looking forward to that, but he will not be coming home until the beginning of May. supporter:HI, how are you today?
seeker:I am not doing well. I am very worried about my son's chances of recovery after so many relapses and frustrated because I know there is really nothing I can do to change things for him.
supporter:You must be very frustrated from feeling unable to do something.
seeker:I am. He is a different person when he's not on drugs but when he is using he can get really mean and he scares me.
supporter:I remember when my mother was having end of life mental declining issues. I understand feeling as if the person is changing and having unusual moods and mood swings.
supporter:Do you have anyone you can talk to?
seeker:I try not to think about the situation, because I don't see him since he lives in another state. But I can't get everything out of my mind. And yes I have my husband to talk to, that helps some. It's when I'm trying to sleep or when my husband isn't home that's the worst for me.
supporter:You are feeling the way anybody in your situation would fee like. It must be helpful to have a husband who listens and can be supportive when he is there.
supporter:Have you always had sleep issues?

seeker:When I'm upset about something I cannot sleep but if I'm in a good state of mind I sleep well.
supporter:Being upset can make someones mind race and make it really difficult to rest or get any sleep at all.
supporter:Have you ever gone through anything like this before?
seeker:Yes I've been dealing with my son's addiction and recovery and relapses for the last three years.
supporter:I can relate to being close to someone who is addicted. It can feel very sad and lonely at times. I would want to change the person in my life but just has to learn to let go instead. It is a process that takes years to learn.

supporter:Yes, I understand how it can feel like our children are always our babies and we want to fix everything for them. Sometimes it feels like we can change them or re raise them if we just do more for them.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hi
supporter:Hello, how are you doing?
seeker:Feeling anxious these days
supporter:Those can be really hard feelings to deal with, but reaching out and acknowledging them is a very positive step. Is their anything in particular making you feel anxious?
seeker:Yes
seeker:I dropped out of graduate school
seeker:Now, I need to get a job, but I'm having difficulty finding jobs for my degrees
seeker:And it's just stressful and depressig
supporter:Drastic changes in our life plans can feel very upsetting and looking for a job in these times is ridiculous.
seeker:Yes, it really is
supporter:What made you feel the need to drop out of graduate school?
seeker:I wasn't finding the program challenging or interesting or a life course I was sure I wanted to go down anymore
seeker:The only jobs I really can do with biology are lab jobs, which are somewhat boring. There are some others, but not many
supporter:I understand that and that was a really brave choice to make before you cornered yourself into a degree that wouldn't benefit your future paths.
seeker:Yea, I think that's true. Other people say that I am a quitter
seeker:They say I quit everything
supporter:Have you gone and smoke to your local job centers? They can often times find suitable jobs or even creative suggestions that can utilize your skills and even grown them.
seeker:No, I'm not aware of any local job centers around me. I mostly have been looking online at places like indeed.com
seeker:I'm not sure what you mean by "job center," I guess, either
supporter:Refusing to finish something that does not benefit your end goal isn't quitting its merely switching strategies to your personal end goal
seeker:Oh, yea. That's a good reframe. I like that.
seeker:I suppose, I'm just getting older and wish I had better, more stable options available to me. All this education hasn't really left with me many hard skills, I feel
supporter:I am from North Carolina and in every city there are job centers, you can look them up by that title, they have people there who can help you find work based on your personality and skills. as well helping with resumes, interveiws, computers, all kinds of things.
seeker:Interesting. I guess I can look into that. I am from Ohio. That's not bad advice.
seeker:I am somewhat kicking myself for paying so much money on education that wasn't really worth that much. I guess there isn't much I can do about that, though
supporter:Im sorry you feel that way but education is never a wasted effort it can only make you level up even if you choose not to actively use what you acquire. Its always nice to have a big back up arsenal so you have options when something you want does turn up.
supporter:Im really glad that suggestion might be helpful for you.
supporter:Have you checked to see if any of the credits you have earned already are transferable to another degree you may find of interest?
seeker:I suppose there can be truth in that. I had a friend say that as well, that education is never a wasted effort. I agree sometimes. I should have thought about the program more before I went into it, but ah, oh well. Nothing I can do about it, now.
seeker:No, it wouldn't be transferable.
seeker:I have though about doing some grad school for something bio related. I don't know.
seeker:I'm 30 now and getting burned out, to be honest
seeker:Anyway, you've said a lot of nice and helpful things. I don't want to take too much time from you. After all, you won your bonus money. But, I really do appreciate you talking to me.

supporter:How can I help you today?
seeker:Hi there. I'm seeking some support, maybe some advice in dealing with a situation at my work.
seeker:I've got a new supervisor who is so different from my last one.
supporter:Sure, I see you need some support at work because your new supervisor is so different than your previous one
supporter:What kinds of things are troubling to you?
seeker:Yes. They have a Military background and bark orders, and change the way I'm working without being open to conversation.
seeker:When I ask questions, they threaten my job. Telling me they "Don't have to explain themselves!" as they are my supervisor.
supporter:Wow, that sounds difficult with them being so militant.  Have you been able to talk to any co-workers in a similar situation?
seeker:Yes, there are two other people supervised by him. One of them is also Military and new him before hand, they seem to get along great.
seeker:But my other co-worker is like me. Doesn't know what to do, or who to turn to.
seeker:Sometimes the work environment is pretty hostile when we're just trying to continue projects that were started before he arrived.
supporter:That sounds hard that it is so hostile at work when you trying so hard.
seeker:Yea. But when he threatens and calls my insubordinate, I worry he might be making a case to remove me.
seeker:I wonder if I should talk to the person above him, about it.
seeker:But I worry they might just think I'm complaining because its different
seeker:But it really is uncomfortable.
supporter:It sounds like you worry about having your job taken away from you.  Talking to someone above your supervisor may be a good solution.
seeker:Its been 3 months since he started, I just wonder if its too soon.
seeker:I'd hate to be seen as a complainer.
seeker:And the person above him, is the person who hired him.
supporter:When I was in a similar situation I had to go to a higher supervisor and was helped a lot. It probably is never too soon, but could be too late if you wait.

seeker:yes, often
seeker:but she won't go for help, so i have had to be exceedingly patient
supporter:I love your patience level and would like to keep it going.
supporter:Patience is the key and she will understand eventually. She will be ready to take help.
seeker:i will but it's such a heavy burden to carry.  i try not to think about it much, but I carry it, you know?   I Hope you are right about her wanting help eventually
seeker:in the meantime I don't know how to be so sad about this, maybe there is no way
supporter:I understand your heavy burden however some kids face these problems and we as parents guide them so that they come out with flying colors.
seeker:indeed.  and i have been holding up my end of the bargain.   but it's so worrisome.
seeker:it sounds like you are encouraging me to have hope against all odds?
supporter:You are a warrior and you need to fight off the worrisome and motivate yourself to help you kiddo.
seeker:CAn't help someone who doesn't want help though, but I do try to be there for her as best i can.   She calls me up with terrible stories and I listen even though it pains me, because she needs someone to listen.
seeker:Addiction is an affliction I wouldn't wish on my worst enemy now that I have seen her living it

supporter:Sorry to hear that I thought close contact will make her vigil and makes her more responsible.

seeker:i am so relieved and happy for her
seeker:just wanted to end up with some good news for you :)
supporter:Oh very nice to hear and super proud of her. I would like to thank you as well.
seeker:Thank you so much for your help today!
seeker:All the best

supporter:I completely understand, my ex-wife also found someone else while we were married and decided she wanted a divorce.
seeker:I don't understand why people even get married if they are going to look for someone else.
seeker:We could of just staid dating.
supporter:Have you asked her about why she started looking for someone else? Sometimes it helps to get some closure and understand the reasons why.
seeker:She won't talk to me.  I am out of state (back home with family).  She told me when I was up here.  She blocked me on everything.  This new person is already living with her or staying there all the time.  When I call this other person answers her phone and talks trash.  She won't let me talk to my wife at all.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:What brings you online today?
supporter:Can I help you with anything today?  We can just chat if you don’t have anything in particular you’d like to discuss.
supporter:I’m Kim.  What’s your name?
seeker:Hi there, I'd love some help
supporter:Great! What’s going on?
seeker:I've been struggling with sleep over the last few months, and it's making me tired during the day.
seeker:I have been finding it hard to stay asleep, and wake up tossing and turning constantly.
supporter:Lack of sleep will definitely make you tired during the day!  Is there something bothering you that causes you to stay awake during the night?
seeker:I can't think of anything particular,  but my mood has been low generally for the last wee while which I imagine is probably the cause. I'm so tired during the day but as soon as my head hits the pillow at night I'm wide awake.
supporter:Well it sounds like you’re tired enough for sleep, but you’re still wired and can’t get the sleep you need.
seeker:That's exactly it. Do you have any advice on what I can do?
supporter:Are you getting any physical activity in during the day to make body more willing to cooperate?
seeker:I'm working in a desk job so spend almost all day sitting down. That could be part of the problem.
supporter:I’ve found that physical activity helps me to get to sleep even when I’m troubled mentally.  Another option is to slow your brain down so that your mind is relaxed.  That is much harder for me though!
seeker:That's a good idea. I could try go out for a walk either before or after work as a starting point and see if that makes a difference.
supporter:That sounds like a good plan!  It also helps to make sure that it’s dark and very quiet.  Surprisingly enough, when they did research on sleep disorders they found that a lot of people just needed quiet and darkness.
seeker:Have you tried lavender? I have heard pillow or room sprays can be good for sleep.
supporter:Yep, I’ve tried a LOT of things.  I’m currently struggling with this myself.  I’m even trying out melatonin, tryptophan, and even CBD (not stoney weed oil)!  So far no success, but I’m still trying!
seeker:I've heard people mention melatonin - I might use that later if other methods dont work. It's good to know other people are in the same boat.
supporter:It’s one of the reasons that it’s good to get outside.  Your body makes melatonin from sunshine, so going for a walk outside helps in 2 ways!
seeker:If we had a little more sunshine where I live that would be fantastic!

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:What brings you online today?
supporter:Can I help you with anything today?  We can just chat if you don’t have anything in particular you’d like to discuss.
supporter:I’m Kim.  What’s your name?
seeker:Hi there, I'd love some help
supporter:Great! What’s going on?
seeker:I've been struggling with sleep over the last few months, and it's making me tired during the day.
seeker:I have been finding it hard to stay asleep, and wake up tossing and turning constantly.
supporter:Lack of sleep will definitely make you tired during the day!  Is there something bothering you that causes you to stay awake during the night?
seeker:I can't think of anything particular,  but my mood has been low generally for the last wee while which I imagine is probably the cause. I'm so tired during the day but as soon as my head hits the pillow at night I'm wide awake.
supporter:Well it sounds like you’re tired enough for sleep, but you’re still wired and can’t get the sleep you need.
seeker:That's exactly it. Do you have any advice on what I can do?
supporter:Are you getting any physical activity in during the day to make body more willing to cooperate?
seeker:I'm working in a desk job so spend almost all day sitting down. That could be part of the problem.
supporter:I’ve found that physical activity helps me to get to sleep even when I’m troubled mentally.  Another option is to slow your brain down so that your mind is relaxed.  That is much harder for me though!
seeker:That's a good idea. I could try go out for a walk either before or after work as a starting point and see if that makes a difference.
supporter:That sounds like a good plan!  It also helps to make sure that it’s dark and very quiet.  Surprisingly enough, when they did research on sleep disorders they found that a lot of people just needed quiet and darkness.
seeker:Have you tried lavender? I have heard pillow or room sprays can be good for sleep.
supporter:Yep, I’ve tried a LOT of things.  I’m currently struggling with this myself.  I’m even trying out melatonin, tryptophan, and even CBD (not stoney weed oil)!  So far no success, but I’m still trying!
seeker:I've heard people mention melatonin - I might use that later if other methods dont work. It's good to know other people are in the same boat.
supporter:It’s one of the reasons that it’s good to get outside.  Your body makes melatonin from sunshine, so going for a walk outside helps in 2 ways!
seeker:If we had a little more sunshine where I live that would be fantastic!
supporter:Getting good sleep is critical.  Supplementing with melatonin might help compensate for your lack of sunshine!
seeker:I'll look into it for sure. It's something I hadnt considered before this chat.
supporter:Glad I could help.
seeker:Thanks, the help was appreciated.
supporter:Anytime.  Is there anything else you wanted to discuss?
seeker:That was all for today, thank you.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello, how are you feeling?
seeker:Tired, very tired!!
supporter:Oh?  How come so tired?
seeker:Because I can't sleep... I don't know what's wrong with me I just lay there awake for hours!
supporter:Oh I have had trouble sleeping before!   Would you like to know what helped me?
seeker:Yes please, I'm desperate, I'll try anything!
supporter:First of all, fixed sleep and wake times.   If you toss and turn for hours, still get up at the same time.   Eventually your body will tire and sleeping will naturally become easier.
seeker:I have to always get up for work so I am sticking to the same routines, I just lie in bed with so many thoughts racing around my head and I just can't get off to sleep
supporter:Second thing I do is I have a wind down routine.   No work past a certain time, no matter what.   Only soft music, pleasant movie, some light reading, and dim the lights.   It slows your body down before sleep.  It will help slow that racing thoughts you are having.
seeker:I did try reading a book last night, but I don't really have lights that I can dim, it's just the one bright light in our room.
supporter:I have had racing thoughts and it used to drive me up the wall!
supporter:Can you buy a lamp?  Even a second hand one if your budget is tight?
seeker:Yeah, it's just so annoying and then I'm so tired and irritable the next day, I find myself snapping at everyone.
supporter:The bright light will keep your mind stimulated.
seeker:I could buy a lamp I suppose, to see if it helps? But when I am awake all night it's in the dark so I'm not sure if the light is the problem>
supporter:Aw so you are so exhausted from racing thoughts and not enough sleep the night before that you end up taking it out on others, but not meaning to.  Am I understanding correctly?
supporter:Do you get any exercise?  I sleep better on days I go for walks, and my sedentary days I sleep worse, it's quite clear to me.
seeker:I have been trying to do lots of walks, I need to lose weight as well so they kind of go hand in hand!
seeker:I do also have back pain so that's another thing that doesn't help!
supporter:Good effort, keep it up!
supporter:Back pain, I know all about that too unfortunately.  How is your mattress?
seeker:Yeah it's a pretty good mattress, but it is a few years old now, I'm not sure how often you're supposed to replace them?
supporter:Hmm I can't recall, I can't afford to replace mine regularly enough lol.  Maybe google it?
seeker:Yeah maybe, at this point it's worth looking into anything that could help!
supporter:Do you have someone to talk to about the thoughts that are racing?
supporter:If they are worries, maybe a counsellor would help.
seeker:Not really, I don't really have any friends and my boyfriends a bit weird about stuff like this, I can't really talk to him about things like this.
seeker:Yeah maybe, I have been considering a counsellor myself.
supporter:Hmm that's a challenge not having friends.   Have been there too!
seeker:And I don't know how to go about finding new ones! I don't think I'm someone people like to be friends with, I try to make friends but they always move on.
supporter:I don't want to give you a huge barrage of suggestions but another thing that helps me is a podcast called Tracks to Relax.
seeker:Sounds interesting, I'll have to look it up!

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello
seeker:Hi there I was hoping you can help me.
supporter:Sure. What can I help you with?
seeker:Well you see I am heartbroken and I can't seem to move on from a previous relationship, and its been over two years. Do you have any advice?
supporter:I’m understand how hard ending a relationship can be.
supporter:What do you find is the hardest thing for you each day. That is, where do you find it hardest to move on?
seeker:Well I would say mentally because I frequently think about her and constantly have memories throughout the day. Also when i hear a certain song or see a restaurant it makes me think of her.
supporter:Memories are a blessing and a curse. Are the memories and thought you are  having positive or negative?
seeker:They are a mix of both because at one point they were positive and now when I think about it, it brings me down in a negative way.
seeker:What have you done in the past to help you move on from a break up?
supporter:It’s hard when we have various emotions. These memories being more negative are hard to cope with. In my experience, if I rethink memories regarding relationships which tend to bring me down in way that is a learning experience, I feel more empowered.
seeker:Yeah I agree that's what I have been doing too, and it's nice to know that you do the same.
supporter:In my past I have been able to try and look at each  relationship as a chance to grow. To figure out what worked with that person and what didn’t. I have them used this as a tool for the future.
seeker:That's a good way to look at it.
supporter:You are making good steps to rethink the situations. Is there anything else contributing to the heat rack you still feel?
supporter:Heartbreak
seeker:Well I have also not met anyone since and fear that I will not fall in love again.
supporter:That is difficult. I understand how it feels to be lonely. Something I’ve done when I’ve felt that way was to learn to fall in love with myself. I like to do self care and make time for things I might not have time for if I were in a relationship.
seeker:hmm interesting I have never thought about falling in love with myself..maybe I will give it a try. Thanks.
supporter:It’s so important to love yourself. Self love breeds confidence and confidence is not only attractive, but powerful in so many ways
seeker:I appreciate the feedback and support, you have helped me take the next step to move on with my life.
supporter:I’m glad I could help. You will overcome this.
seeker:Thank you and hope to talk to you again. Have a good night.

seeker:plus finish up the assignment and I have a part-time job, and plus doing some catching with the other course which is all due next month after this course.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hello?
supporter:Hello!
supporter:How are you doing tonight?
seeker:I'm doing alright
seeker:How about you?
supporter:You are doing well?  That is great to hear.  I am the support provider, do you have any questions or problems?
seeker:I've just been feeling a little down about the breakup, even though it was like 4 years ago
supporter:So it was almost four years ago, but you still feel depressed when you think about it?
seeker:Yes
supporter:That must be difficult for you, to still feel that way.
seeker:Initially, I was sad about being heart broken, but later I became more concerned about why I had a strange complex I never even knew I had
seeker:Which I never discovered until recently
supporter:Being upset and heartbroken is very understandable, but what do you mean by a strange complex?
seeker:When I first met my partner, she was at a low point in her life
supporter:So you really feel she was depressed or upset when you met her?
seeker:Yea
supporter:Did her being depressed have an effect on you?
seeker:Naturally, I wanted to help her, even though I felt somewhat uncomfortable at first
supporter:of course you were sympathetic towards her pain, that is totally understandable.
seeker:So I stuck with her and saw her become better
seeker:even made some friends along the way
supporter:That sounds great, that you were able to help her out in that way.
seeker:However, I suddenly started to feel a little depressed for some reason
supporter:So as she became better, you started to feel worse?
seeker:I believe it's because I felt useless after that point
supporter:That's interesting, so you feel that you were together so long as you could help her, but then you lost interest in her?
seeker:I didn't lose interest, it was just that I had this strange complex where I needed to feel needed
supporter:or did she reject you once she felt better?
seeker:She said that she was busy with other stuff
supporter:Has that happened to you in other relationships?
seeker:Never been in another one
seeker:I've had crushes, but it never went past that for various reasons
supporter:So you have not had any successful relationships since then?  Do you think that is why you feel depressed?
seeker:I don't think so
seeker:The thing is, I'm still friends with her
supporter:So that is good, that even after the end of your romantic relationship you were still able to maintain a friendship.
seeker:It's rather awkward, tho. We don't even talk often
supporter:Have you thought about volunteering in a position where you could be helpful to others?
supporter:So you feel that you are still friends even though you don't speak to each other often?
seeker:I've done such thing during the summer

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hi, how are you? I am dealing with a lot right now!
supporter:Hello! How can I help?
supporter:What is wrong?
seeker:My job is driving me nuts! I can't handle it anymore.
supporter:How is it driving you nuts?
seeker:The pressure has been building and building. They keep giving me more responsibility, but no more help! The pandemic has really made my job a lot harder.
supporter:I have also went through the same thing as you and I know how hard it feels, so believe in yourself
supporter:You have been given responsibility because you are competent enough to carry it out
seeker:I want to quit the job and get away from the pressure. I'm worried about my mental health and also about the risk of COVID.
seeker:I think that's the problem! I'm TOO competent.
supporter:Don't quit your job because it will only make life harder in the long run
seeker:I think the company wouldn't give me so much work if I were worse at my job. The reward for doing a good job is more work!
seeker:I know, I know! But the anxiety is killing me! Every day at work is worse than the last!
supporter:Being competent is good and you will surely get compensation for the amount of work you put in, maybe a promotion
seeker:I don't want to quit. How do I find a balance? How do I manage my anxiety?
seeker:I don't think the company wants to give me a promotion because that would cost them more money. Maybe another company would pay me better.
supporter:You could always work harder and show them you can work, maybe then they will offer you a promotion
supporter:You can manage your anxiety by maybe meditating, it seems you have a lot going on so it would help to forget about things for a while
seeker:I have never tried meditation. That's a good idea. Maybe some other people at the company would like to try it too.
supporter:Yeah! Get others to do it with you and you may start to feel more comfortable
seeker:That's true. Meditation is a good way to get in contact with my emotions. It might help me not feel so isolated.
supporter:Yeah! You are never alone you can always get through this
seeker:Yeah. I *can* get through this, if I reach out to others at the company. Maybe not the managers, but the other employees certainly know what I'm going through.
supporter:Yes and maybe they are going through the same thing so they would like to find a solution as well
seeker:I feel the anxiety getting better. I know that others have tried meditation to deal with stress and anxiety. It's a good suggestion. Thanks!
